name: %INCLUDE
description: Brings a SAS programming statement, data lines, or both, into a current SAS program.

arguments.name: 'external-file'
arguments.description: specifies the physical name of an external file that is enclosed in quotation marks. The physical name is the name by which the operating environment recognizes the file.

arguments.name: fileref
arguments.description: specifies a fileref that has previously been associated with an external file.

arguments.name: fileref
arguments.description: specifies a fileref that has previously been associated with an aggregate storage location. Follow the fileref with one or more filenames that reside in that location. Enclose the filenames in one set of parentheses, and separate each filename with a comma followed by a space.

arguments.name: internal-lines
arguments.description: includes lines that were entered earlier in the same SAS job or session.

prompts you to enter data from the keyboard. Place an asterisk (*) after the %INCLUDE statement in your code: To resume processing the original source program, enter a %RUN statement from the keyboard.

arguments.name: SOURCE2
arguments.description: causes the SAS log to show the source statements that are being included in your SAS program.

arguments.name: S2=
arguments.description: specifies the length of the record to be used for input. Length can have these values:

arguments.name: BLKSIZE=
arguments.description: specifies the number of bytes that are physically read or written in an I/O operation.

arguments.name: ENCODING=
arguments.description: specifies the encoding to use when reading from the specified source. The value for ENCODING= indicates that the specified source has a different encoding from the current session encoding.

arguments.name: LRECL=
arguments.description: specifies the logical record length (in bytes).

arguments.name: RECFM=
arguments.description: specifies the record format. The following values are valid:

name: %LIST
description: Displays lines that are entered in the current session.

arguments.name: n
arguments.description: displays line n.

arguments.name: n–m
arguments.description: displays lines n through m.

name: %RUN
description: Ends source statements following a %INCLUDE * statement.

name: AXIS
description: Controls the location, values, and appearance of the axes in plots and charts.

arguments.name: COLOR=
arguments.description: specifies the color for all axis components (the axis line, all tick marks, the frame outline, and all text) unless you include a more explicit AXIS statement color specification.

arguments.name: INTERVAL=
arguments.description: The INTERVAL option affects the LOGBASE option in the AXIS statement.

arguments.name: LABEL=
arguments.description: modifies an axis label.

arguments.name: ANGLE=
arguments.description: specifies the angle of the baseline with respect to the horizontal. A positive value for degrees moves the baseline counterclockwise; a negative value moves it clockwise. By default, ANGLE=0 (horizontal) unless the text is automatically angled or rotated to avoid overlapping.

arguments.name: COLOR=
arguments.description: specifies the color for the text. If you omit the COLOR= option, a color specification is searched for in this order:

arguments.name: FONT=
arguments.description: specifies the font for the text. See for details about specifying font. If you omit the FONT= option, a font specification is searched for in this order:

arguments.name: HEIGHT=
arguments.description: specifies the height of the text characters in number of units. If you omit the HEIGHT= option, a text height specification is searched for in this order:

arguments.name: JUSTIFY=
arguments.description:
specifies the alignment of the text. The default depends on the option with which it is used and the text that it applies to.
• With the LABEL= option, the following is true: 
• For a left vertical axis label, the default is         JUSTIFY=RIGHT.
• for a right vertical axis label, the default is         JUSTIFY=LEFT.
• for a horizontal axis label, the default is         JUSTIFY=CENTER.
• With the REFLABEL= option, the following is true: 
• For a reference line that intersects a vertical         axis, the default is JUSTIFY=CENTER. RIGHT places the text string on the right end of the         line. CENTER places the text string in the middle of the line. LEFT places the text string         to the left of the line.
• For a reference line that intersects a         horizontal axis, the default is JUSTIFY=RIGHT for all procedures except the BAR statement in         GBARLINE. For the BAR statement in GBARLINE the default is JUSTIFY=LEFT. RIGHT places the         text string just to the right of the line. CENTER centers the text string on top of the         line. LEFT places the text string just to the left of the line.
• With the VALUE= option, the following is true: 
• For         numeric variables on a vertical axis, the default is JUSTIFY=LEFT, starting with SAS/GRAPH         release 9.2. Specify JUSTIFY=RIGHT to align the variable values according to release 9.1 and         earlier behavior.
• For character variables on a vertical axis, the         default is JUSTIFY=LEFT.
• For all variables on a horizontal axis, the         default is JUSTIFY=CENTER.

arguments.name: ROTATE=
arguments.description: specifies the angle at which each character of text is rotated with respect to the baseline of the text string. A positive value for degree rotates the character counterclockwise; a negative value moves it clockwise. By default, ROTATE=0 (parallel to the baseline) unless the text is automatically angled or rotated to avoid overlapping.

arguments.name: "text-string"
arguments.description: provides up to 256 characters of label text. By default, the text of the axis label is either the variable name or a previously assigned variable label. Enclose each string in quotation marks. Separate multiple strings with blanks.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: suppresses the axis label.

arguments.name: LENGTH=
arguments.description: specifies the length of the axis in number of units.

arguments.name: LOGBASE=
arguments.description: scales the axis values logarithmically according to the value specified.

arguments.name: LOGSTYLE=
arguments.description: specifies whether the values displayed on the logarithmic axis are the values of the base or the values of the power.

arguments.name: MAJOR=
arguments.description: modifies the major tick marks.

arguments.name: COLOR=
arguments.description: specifies the color of the major tick marks

arguments.name: HEIGHT=
arguments.description: specifies the vertical height of the major tick marks

arguments.name: NUMBER=
arguments.description: specifies the number of the major tick marks

arguments.name: WIDTH=
arguments.description: specifies the width of the major tick marks

arguments.name: MINOR=
arguments.description: modifies the minor tick marks that appear between major tick marks.

arguments.name: COLOR=
arguments.description: specifies the color of the minor tick marks

arguments.name: HEIGHT=
arguments.description: specifies the vertical height of the minor tick marks

arguments.name: NUMBER=
arguments.description: specifies the number of the minor tick marks

arguments.name: WIDTH=
arguments.description: specifies the width of the minor tick marks

arguments.name: NOBRACKETS
arguments.description: suppresses the printing of group brackets drawn around the values on the group axis in a bar chart.

arguments.name: NOPLANE
arguments.description: removes either the horizontal or vertical three-dimensional axis plane in bar charts produced by the HBAR3D and VBAR3D statements.

arguments.name: OFFSET=
arguments.description: specifies the distance from the first and last major tick marks or bars to the ends of the axis line.

arguments.name: ORDER=
arguments.description: specifies the order in which data values appear on the axis.

arguments.name: value-list
value-list
arguments.description: For character variables, value-list is a list of unique character values enclosed in quotation marks and separated by blanks:

arguments.name: D
arguments.description: date

arguments.name: T
arguments.description: time

arguments.name: DT
arguments.description: datetime

arguments.name: DAY
arguments.description: default interval for date

arguments.name: SECOND
arguments.description: default interval for time

arguments.name: DTSECOND
arguments.description: default interval for datetime

arguments.name: ORIGIN=
arguments.description: specifies the x coordinate and the y coordinate of the origin of the axis.

arguments.name: REFLABEL=
arguments.description: creates and defines the appearance of a reference-line label.

arguments.name: ANGLE=
arguments.description: specifies the angle of the baseline with respect to the horizontal. A positive value for degrees moves the baseline counterclockwise; a negative value moves it clockwise. By default, ANGLE=0 (horizontal) unless the text is automatically angled or rotated to avoid overlapping.

arguments.name: AUTOREF
arguments.description: automatically labels each reference line on an axis with the response value at the reference line's position.

arguments.name: COLOR=
arguments.description: specifies the color for the text. If you omit the COLOR= option, a color specification is searched for in this order:

arguments.name: FONT=
arguments.description: specifies the font for the text. See for details about specifying font. If you omit the FONT= option, a font specification is searched for in this order:

arguments.name: FORMAT=
arguments.description: specifies a valid format to be applied to the response-axis value shown with the AUTOREF label on each reference line.

arguments.name: HEIGHT=
arguments.description: specifies the height of the text characters in number of units. If you omit the HEIGHT= option, a text height specification is searched for in this order:

arguments.name: JUSTIFY=
arguments.description:
specifies the alignment of the text. The default depends on the option with which it is used and the text that it applies to.
• With the LABEL= option, the following is true: 
• For a left vertical axis label, the default is         JUSTIFY=RIGHT.
• for a right vertical axis label, the default is         JUSTIFY=LEFT.
• for a horizontal axis label, the default is         JUSTIFY=CENTER.
• With the REFLABEL= option, the following is true: 
• For a reference line that intersects a vertical         axis, the default is JUSTIFY=CENTER. RIGHT places the text string on the right end of the         line. CENTER places the text string in the middle of the line. LEFT places the text string         to the left of the line.
• For a reference line that intersects a         horizontal axis, the default is JUSTIFY=RIGHT for all procedures except the BAR statement in         GBARLINE. For the BAR statement in GBARLINE the default is JUSTIFY=LEFT. RIGHT places the         text string just to the right of the line. CENTER centers the text string on top of the         line. LEFT places the text string just to the left of the line.
• With the VALUE= option, the following is true: 
• For         numeric variables on a vertical axis, the default is JUSTIFY=LEFT, starting with SAS/GRAPH         release 9.2. Specify JUSTIFY=RIGHT to align the variable values according to release 9.1 and         earlier behavior.
• For character variables on a vertical axis, the         default is JUSTIFY=LEFT.
• For all variables on a horizontal axis, the         default is JUSTIFY=CENTER.

arguments.name: POSITION=
arguments.description:
specifies the position of a reference-line label relative to the reference line. The default is TOP for both vertical and horizontal reference lines. The POSITION= option is available only on the REFLABEL= option.
• For horizontal reference lines, TOP places              the label just above the reference line. MIDDLE places the label on the reference line.              BOTTOM places the label just below the reference line.
• For vertical reference lines, TOP places              the label at the top end of the reference line. MIDDLE places the label in the middle              of the line. BOTTOM places the label at the bottom end of the line.

arguments.name: ROTATE=
arguments.description: specifies the angle at which each character of text is rotated with respect to the baseline of the text string. A positive value for degree rotates the character counterclockwise; a negative value moves it clockwise. By default, ROTATE=0 (parallel to the baseline) unless the text is automatically angled or rotated to avoid overlapping.

arguments.name: TICK=
arguments.description: specifies the n reference line or tick mark value. Used only with the REFLABEL= option or the VALUE= option. If neither one is specified, then the TICK= option is ignored. • With the REFLABEL= option, the TICK= option specifies the nth reference line. It is used to limit modifications to individual reference lines when there are multiple reference lines on an axis. For example, the following option changes the color of only the third reference line's label and leaves all other reference-line labels unchanged: • With the VALUE= option, the TICK= option specifies the nth value. It is used to designate the tick mark value whose text and appearance you want to modify. For example, the following option changes the color of only the third tick mark value and leaves all others unchanged:

arguments.name: "text-string"
arguments.description: provides up to 256 characters of label text. By default, a reference line does not have a label. Enclose each string in quotation marks. Separate multiple strings with blank spaces. The strings are applied to the reference lines specified by the VREF or HREF option.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: suppresses the reference-line label.

arguments.name: SPLIT=
arguments.description: specifies one or more characters that the AXIS statement uses to break axis values into multiple lines.

arguments.name: STAGGER
arguments.description: offsets the axis values on a horizontal axis.

arguments.name: STYLE=
arguments.description: specifies a line type for the axis line.

arguments.name: VALUE=
arguments.description: modifies the text that labels the major tick marks on the axis.

arguments.name: ANGLE=
arguments.description: specifies the angle of the baseline with respect to the horizontal. A positive value for degrees moves the baseline counterclockwise; a negative value moves it clockwise. By default, ANGLE=0 (horizontal) unless the text is automatically angled or rotated to avoid overlapping.

arguments.name: COLOR=
arguments.description: specifies the color for the text. If you omit the COLOR= option, a color specification is searched for in this order:

arguments.name: FONT=
arguments.description: specifies the font for the text. See for details about specifying font. If you omit the FONT= option, a font specification is searched for in this order:

arguments.name: HEIGHT=
arguments.description: specifies the height of the text characters in number of units. If you omit the HEIGHT= option, a text height specification is searched for in this order:

specifies the alignment of the text. The default depends on the option with which it is used and the text that it applies to.
• With the LABEL= option, the following is true:

• With the REFLABEL= option, the following is true:

• For a reference line that intersects a         horizontal axis, the default is JUSTIFY=RIGHT for all procedures except the BAR statement in         GBARLINE. For the BAR statement in GBARLINE the default is JUSTIFY=LEFT. RIGHT places the         text string just to the right of the line. CENTER centers the text string on top of the         line. LEFT places the text string just to the left of the line.
• With the VALUE= option, the following is true: 
• For         numeric variables on a vertical axis, the default is JUSTIFY=LEFT, starting with SAS/GRAPH         release 9.2. Specify JUSTIFY=RIGHT to align the variable values according to release 9.1 and         earlier behavior.
• For character variables on a vertical axis, the         default is JUSTIFY=LEFT.
• For all variables on a horizontal axis, the         default is JUSTIFY=CENTER.

arguments.name: ROTATE=
arguments.description: specifies the angle at which each character of text is rotated with respect to the baseline of the text string. A positive value for degree rotates the character counterclockwise; a negative value moves it clockwise. By default, ROTATE=0 (parallel to the baseline) unless the text is automatically angled or rotated to avoid overlapping.

arguments.name: TICK=
arguments.description: specifies the n reference line or tick mark value. Used only with the REFLABEL= option or the VALUE= option. If neither one is specified, then the TICK= option is ignored. • With the REFLABEL= option, the TICK= option specifies the nth reference line. It is used to limit modifications to individual reference lines when there are multiple reference lines on an axis. For example, the following option changes the color of only the third reference line's label and leaves all other reference-line labels unchanged: • With the VALUE= option, the TICK= option specifies the nth value. It is used to designate the tick mark value whose text and appearance you want to modify. For example, the following option changes the color of only the third tick mark value and leaves all others unchanged:

arguments.name: "text-string"
arguments.description: provides up to 256 characters of text for the major tick mark value. By default, the value is either the variable value or an associated format value. Enclose each string in quotation marks and separate multiple strings with blanks.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: suppresses the major tick mark labels, although the major tick marks are still displayed.

arguments.name: WIDTH=
arguments.description: specifies the thickness of the axis line.

arguments.name: COLOR=
arguments.description: colors the tick marks. If you omit the COLOR= suboption, a color specification is searched for in this order:

arguments.name: HEIGHT=
arguments.description:
specifies the height of the tick mark. The defaults for the HEIGHT= suboption depend on the option with which it is used:
• With the MAJOR= option the default height  .5 CELLS.
• With the MINOR= option the default height  .25 CELLS.

arguments.name: NUMBER=
arguments.description: specifies the number of tick marks to be drawn. With the MAJOR= option, number-of-ticks must be greater than 1. With the MINOR= option, number-of-ticks must be greater than 0.

arguments.name: WIDTH=
arguments.description: specifies the thickness of the tick mark, where thickness-factor is a number. Thickness increases directly with thickness-factor. By default, WIDTH=1.

name: CATNAME
description: Logically combines two or more catalogs into one by associating them with a catref (a shortcut name); clears one or all catrefs; lists the concatenated catalogs in one concatenation or in all concatenations.

arguments.name: libref
arguments.description: is any previously assigned SAS libref. If you do not specify a libref, SAS concatenates the catalog in the Work library, using the catref that you specify.

arguments.name: catref
arguments.description: is a unique catalog reference name for a catalog or a catalog concatenation that is specified in the statement. Separate the catref from the libref with a period, as in libref.catref. Any SAS name can be used for this catref.

arguments.name: catalog
arguments.description: is the name of a catalog that is available for use in the catalog concatenation.

arguments.name: CLEAR
arguments.description: disassociates a currently assigned catref or libref.catref.

arguments.name: _ALL_ CLEAR
arguments.description: disassociates all currently assigned catref or libref.catref concatenations.

arguments.name: LIST
arguments.description: writes the catalog names that are included in the specified concatenation to the SAS log.

arguments.name: _ALL_ LIST
arguments.description: writes all catalog names that are included in any current catalog concatenation to the SAS log.

arguments.name: ACCESS=
arguments.description: assigns a read-only attribute to the catalog. SAS allows users to read from the catalog entries but not to update information or to write new information.

name: ENDSAS
description: Stops SAS program execution as soon as the statement is encountered in a SAS program.

name: FILENAME
description: Associates a SAS fileref with an external file or an output device, disassociates a fileref and external file, or lists attributes of external files.

arguments.name: fileref
arguments.description: is any SAS name that you use when you assign a new fileref. When you disassociate a currently assigned fileref or when you list file attributes with the FILENAME statement, specify a fileref that was previously assigned with a FILENAME statement.

arguments.name: AZURE
arguments.description: specifies an access method that enables you to access data in Microsoft Azure Data Lake Storage.

arguments.name: AZURE
arguments.description: specifies an access method that enables you to access data in Microsoft Azure Blob Storage.in Microsoft Azure Data Lake Storage.

arguments.name: CATALOG
arguments.description: specifies an access method that enables you to reference a SAS catalog as an external file.

arguments.name: CLIPBOARD
arguments.description: specifies an access method that enables you to read text data from and write text data to the clipboard on the host computer.

arguments.name: DATAURL
arguments.description: specifies an access method that enables you to read data from user-specified text.

arguments.name: DISK
arguments.description: specifies that the device is a disk drive.

arguments.name: DUMMY
arguments.description: specifies that the output to the file is discarded.

arguments.name: EMAIL
arguments.description: specifies an access method that enables you to send electronic mail programmatically from SAS by using the SMTP (Simple Mail Transfer Protocol) email interface.

arguments.name: FILESRVC
arguments.description: specifies an access method that enables you to store and retrieve user content using the SAS Viya Files service.

arguments.name: FTP
arguments.description: specifies an access method that enables you to access remote files by using the FTP protocol.

arguments.name: GCS
arguments.description: specifies an access method that enables you to access data in Google Cloud Storage.

arguments.name: GTERM
arguments.description: indicates that the output device type is a graphics device that receives graphics data.

arguments.name: HADOOP
arguments.description: specifies an access method that enables you to access files on a Hadoop Distributed File System (HDFS) whose location is specified in a configuration file.

arguments.name: PIPE
arguments.description: specifies an unnamed pipe.

arguments.name: PLOTTER
arguments.description: specifies an unbuffered graphics output device.

arguments.name: PRINTER
arguments.description: specifies a printer or printer spool file.

arguments.name: S3
arguments.description: specifies an access method that enables you to access Amazon S3 files.

arguments.name: SOCKET
arguments.description: specifies an access method that enables you to read from or write to a TCP/IP socket.

arguments.name: TAPE
arguments.description: specifies a tape drive.

arguments.name: TEMP
arguments.description: creates a temporary file that exists only as long as the filename is assigned. The temporary file can be accessed only through the logical name and is available only while the logical name exists.

arguments.name: TERMINAL
arguments.description: specifies the user's terminal.

arguments.name: UPRINTER
arguments.description: specifies a Universal Printing printer definition name.

arguments.name: URL
arguments.description: specifies an access method that enables you to access remote files by using the URL access method.

arguments.name: WEBDAV
arguments.description: specifies an access method that enables you to access remote files by using the WebDAV protocol.

arguments.name: ZIP
arguments.description: specifies an access method that enables you to access ZIP files.

arguments.name: 'external-file'
arguments.description: is the physical name of an external file. The physical name is the name that is recognized by the operating environment. Linux filenames are case sensitive.

arguments.name: 'pathname-1'
arguments.description: are pathnames for the files that you want to access with the same fileref. Use this form of the FILENAME statement when you want to concatenate filenames. Concatenation of filenames is available only for DISK files, so you do not have to specify the device-type. Separate the pathnames with either commas or blank spaces. Enclose each pathname in quotation marks. Remember that Linux filenames are case-sensitive.

arguments.name: directory-name
arguments.description: specifies the directory that contains the files that you want to access.

arguments.name: access-method
arguments.description: specifies the access method or device type that is used if the fileref points to an input or output device or location that is not a physical file. describes the information that is expected by the access method.

arguments.name: access-information
arguments.description: differs according to the access method. shows the information appropriate to each access method.

arguments.name: ENCODING=
arguments.description: specifies the encoding to use when SAS is reading from or writing to an external file. The value for ENCODING= indicates that the external file has a different encoding from the current session encoding.

arguments.name: CLEAR
arguments.description: disassociates one or more currently assigned filerefs.

arguments.name: _ALL_
arguments.description: specifies that the CLEAR or LIST argument applies to all currently assigned filerefs.

arguments.name: LIST
arguments.description: writes the attributes of one or more files to the SAS log.

arguments.name: BLKSIZE=
arguments.description: specifies the number of bytes that are physically written or read in one I/O operation. The default is 64K. The maximum is 1G-1.

arguments.name: LOCKINTERNAL=
arguments.description: specifies the SAS system locking that is to be used for the files that are listed in a FILENAME statement. For more information, see .

arguments.name: AUTO
arguments.description: locks a file so that in a SAS session, if a user has Write access to a file, then no other users can have Read or Write access to the file. If a user has Read access to a file, no other user can have Write access to the file, but multiple users can have Read access.

arguments.name: SHARED
arguments.description: locks a file so that in a SAS session, two users do not have simultaneous Write access to the file. The file can be shared simultaneously by one user who has Write access and multiple users who have Read access.

arguments.name: LRECL=
arguments.description: specifies the logical record length. Its value depends on the record format in effect (RECFM).

arguments.name: MOD
arguments.description: indicates that data written to the file should be appended to the file.

arguments.name: NEWOLD
arguments.description: specifies whether a new or existing file is used for output. If you specify NEW, a new file is to be opened for output. If the file already exists, it is deleted and re-created. If you specify OLD, the previous contents of the file are replaced. NEW is the default.

arguments.name: PERMISSION=
arguments.description: specifies permissions to set for the specified fileref. To specify more than one set of permission values, separate them with a comma within quotation marks.

arguments.name: RECFM=
arguments.description: specifies the record format of the external file.

arguments.name: TERMSTR=
arguments.description: controls the end-of-line delimiter in files that are formatted by Linux. By default, either a line feed alone or a carriage return and a line feed indicate the end of a line. To explicitly define the end-of-line delimiter, specify one of the following values:

arguments.name: UNBUF
arguments.description: tells SAS not to perform buffered Writes to the file on any subsequent FILE statement. This option applies especially when you are reading from or writing to a data collection device. It also prevents buffered Reads on INFILE statements.

name: FOOTNOTE
description: Controls the content, appearance, and placement of text in a footnote.

arguments.description: specifies the relative line that contains the footnote text.

arguments.name: BCOLOR=
arguments.description: specifies the background color of the footnote block.

arguments.name: BOLD
arguments.description: specifies that the font weight is bold for the text string.

arguments.name: COLOR=
arguments.description: specifies the color for the text. You can specify colors using a number of different color-naming schemes. For more information, see .

arguments.name: FONT=
arguments.description: specifies the system font to use for the text string. If you supply multiple fonts, then the destination device uses the first one that is installed on your system.

arguments.name: HEIGHT=
arguments.description: specifies the size of the text. You can also specify the unit of measurement. Without a unit of measure, the number becomes a relative size.

arguments.name: numeric-value
arguments.description: The value of size is relative to all other font sizes in the HTML document.

arguments.name: units
arguments.description: is a nonnegative number.

arguments.name: ITALIC
arguments.description: specifies that the font style is italic for the text string.

arguments.name: JUSTIFY=
arguments.description: specifies the alignment of the text string. You can specify one of the following values:

arguments.name: LEFT
arguments.description: specifies left justification.

arguments.name: CENTER
arguments.description: aligns the text in the center.

arguments.name: RIGHT
arguments.description: aligns the text to the right.

arguments.name: LINK=
arguments.description: specifies a uniform resource locator (URL) to which a footnote links.

arguments.name: UNDERLIN=
arguments.description: specifies whether the subsequent text is underlined. UNDERLIN=0 indicates no underlining. Values 1, 2, and 3 indicate the same type of underlining.

arguments.name: ALT=
arguments.description: specifies descriptive text for a URL to which a footnote links, or the footnote itself.

arguments.name: ANGLE=
arguments.description: specifies the angle of the baseline of the entire text string with respect to the horizontal.

arguments.name: BLANK=
arguments.description: protects the box and its contents from being overwritten by any subsequent graphics elements.

arguments.name: BOX=
arguments.description: draws a box around one line of text.

arguments.name: BSPACE=
arguments.description: specifies the amount of space between the text and the border of a box that you create with the BOX= option.

arguments.name: DRAW=
arguments.description: draws lines anywhere on the graphics output area.

arguments.name: LANGLE=
arguments.description: specifies the angle of one or more than one entire text-string.

arguments.name: LSPACE=
arguments.description: specifies the amount of space above lines of footnote text.

arguments.name: MOVE=
arguments.description: positions a text string.

arguments.name: ROTATE=
arguments.description: specifies the angle at which each character of text is rotated.

arguments.name: WRAP
arguments.description: wraps a text string containing a blank to a second line if the text does not fit on one line.

arguments.name: 'text-string'
arguments.description: is a text string with a maximum length of 255 bytes. You must enclose text strings in either single or double quotation marks. The text appears exactly as you enter it in the statement, including uppercase and lowercase characters and spaces. Footnotes automatically wrap to additional lines if necessary. If the length of the specified title is greater than the value of the LINESIZE option, the title is truncated to the line size.

name: GOPTIONS
description: Temporarily sets default values for many graphics attributes and device parameters used by SAS/GRAPH procedures.

arguments.name: options-list
arguments.description: can be one or more options as listed and described in the .

arguments.name: ACCESSIBLE
arguments.description: when used with an HTML ODS destination, generates descriptive text and data for your graphs to comply with section 508 of the Rehabilitation Acts and to meet usability requirements for disabled users.

arguments.name: ALTDESC
arguments.description: when used with an HTML ODS destination, includes an HTML ALT tag in the HTML output that specifies alternate text for the graph.

arguments.name: ASPECT=
arguments.description: Sets the aspect ratio for graphics elements.

arguments.name: scaling-factor
arguments.description: specifies a nonnegative integer or real number that determines the ratio of width to height for graphics elements.

arguments.name: AUTOCOPY
arguments.description: prints a copy of the graph automatically.

arguments.name: AUTOFEED
arguments.description: causes the device to feed new paper automatically for the next graph.

arguments.name: AUTOSIZE=
arguments.description: Controls whether to change the size of the character cells in order to preserve the number of rows and columns specified in the device entry.

arguments.name: ON
arguments.description: changes the cell size in order to preserve the number of rows and columns.

arguments.name: OFF
arguments.description: preserves the device's original cell size and temporarily changes the number of rows and columns.

arguments.name: DEFAULT
arguments.description: uses the default setting (ON or OFF) that is controlled by DEVOPTS bit 50.

arguments.name: BINDING=
arguments.description: Specifies which edge of the document is the binding edge.

arguments.name: BORDER
arguments.description: draws a border around the graphics output area.

arguments.name: CBACK=
arguments.description: Specifies the background color of the graphics output.

arguments.name: background-color
arguments.description: specifies the background color using any SAS/GRAPH color name.

arguments.name: CBY=
arguments.description: Selects the color of the BY lines that appear in the graphics output.

arguments.name: By
arguments.description: specifies the By-line color using any SAS/GRAPH color name.

arguments.name: CELL
arguments.description: causes the device to use cell alignment.

arguments.name: CHARACTERS
arguments.description: causes SAS/GRAPH to use the device-resident font when you do not specify a font in a SAS program.

arguments.name: CHARTYPE=
arguments.description: Selects the number of the default hardware character set.

arguments.name: hardware-font-chartype
arguments.description: specifies the hardware font character type as an integer in the range 0–999.

arguments.name: CIRCLEARC
arguments.description: causes SAS/GRAPH to use the built-in hardware circle- and arc-drawing capability of the device.

arguments.name: COLLATE
arguments.description: Specifies whether to collate the output, if collation is supported by the device.

arguments.name: COLORS=
arguments.description: Specifies the colors used to produce your graphics output if you do not specify colors explicitly in program statements.

arguments.name: colors-list
arguments.description: specifies one or more SAS color names.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: tells SAS/GRAPH to use only the colors that you explicitly specify in program statements and to ignore the ODS style colors.

arguments.name: CPATTERN=
arguments.description: Selects the default color for PATTERN definitions when a color has not been specified.

arguments.name: pattern-color
arguments.description: specifies the pattern color using any SAS/GRAPH color name.

arguments.name: CSYMBOL=
arguments.description: Specifies the default color for SYMBOL definitions when a color has not been specified.

arguments.name: symbol-color
arguments.description: specifies the symbol color using any SAS/GRAPH color name.

arguments.name: CTEXT=
arguments.description: Selects the default color for all text and the border.

arguments.name: text-color
arguments.description: specifies the text color using any SAS/GRAPH color name.

arguments.name: CTITLE=
arguments.description: Selects the default color for all titles, footnotes, and notes, and the border.

arguments.name: title-color
arguments.description: specifies the title color using any SAS/GRAPH color name.

arguments.name: DASH
arguments.description: causes SAS/GRAPH to use the built-in hardware dashed-line drawing capability of the device when generating graphics output.

arguments.name: DASHSCALE=
arguments.description: Scales the lengths of the dashes in a dashed line.

arguments.name: scaling-factor
arguments.description: can be any number greater than 0.

arguments.name: DELAY=
arguments.description: Controls the amount of time between graphs in the animation sequence.

arguments.name: delay-time
arguments.description: specifies the length of time between graphs in units of 0.01 seconds.

arguments.name: DEVADDR=
arguments.description: Specifies the location of the device to which the output of device drivers is sent.

arguments.name: device-address
arguments.description: specifies the address of the device to which the device driver output is to be sent.

arguments.name: DEVICE=
arguments.description: Specifies the device driver to which SAS/GRAPH sends the procedure output. The device driver controls the format of graphics output.

arguments.name: device-entry
arguments.description: specifies the name of a device entry that is stored in a device catalog.

arguments.name: DEVMAP=
arguments.description: Specifies the device map to be used when device-resident fonts are used.

arguments.name: device-map-name
arguments.description: is a string up to eight characters long that is the name of the device map entry.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: specifies that you do not want to use a device map.

arguments.name: DISPLAY
arguments.description: displays the graph output.

arguments.name: DISPOSAL=
arguments.description: Specifies what happens to the graphic after it is displayed.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: causes the graphic to be left in place after displaying.

arguments.name: BACKGROUND
arguments.description: causes the background color to be returned and the graph erased after displaying.

arguments.name: PREVIOUS
arguments.description: causes the graphic area to be restored with what was displayed in the area previously.

arguments.name: UNSPECIFIED
arguments.description: indicates that no action is necessary.

arguments.name: DRVINIT1=
arguments.description: Specifies host commands to be executed before driver initialization.

arguments.name: system-command
arguments.description: specifies a character string of up to 72 characters that contains one or more valid system commands and can be in upper- or lowercase letters.

arguments.name: DRVINIT2=
arguments.description: Specifies host commands to be executed before driver initialization.

arguments.name: system-command
arguments.description: specifies a character string of up to 72 characters that contains one or more valid system commands and can be in upper- or lowercase letters.

arguments.name: DRVTERM1=
arguments.description: Specifies host commands to be executed after the driver terminates.

arguments.name: system-command
arguments.description: specifies a character string of up to 72 characters that contains one or more valid system commands and can be in upper- or lowercase letters.

arguments.name: DRVTERM2=
arguments.description: Specifies host commands to be executed after the driver terminates.

arguments.name: system-command
arguments.description: specifies a character string of up to 72 characters that contains one or more valid system commands and can be in upper- or lowercase letters.

arguments.name: DUPLEX
arguments.description: specifies that duplex printing can be used if it is available on the device.

arguments.name: ERASE
arguments.description: causes the graph to be erased when you press Enter after the graph has been displayed.

arguments.name: EXTENSION=
arguments.description: Specifies the file extension for an external graphics file.

arguments.name: file-type
arguments.description: a string up to eight characters long that is a file extension, such as GIF or CGM, that you want to append to an external file.

arguments.name: FASTTEXT
arguments.description: specifies that integer-based font processing is to be used for faster font rendering.

arguments.name: FBY=
arguments.description: Selects the font for BY lines.

arguments.name: By
arguments.description: specifies the font for all BY lines on the graphics output.

arguments.name: FCACHE=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of system fonts to keep open at one time.

arguments.name: number-fonts-open
arguments.description: specifies the number of system fonts to keep open. Number-fonts-open must be greater than or equal to zero.

arguments.name: FILECLOSE=
arguments.description: Controls when the graphics stream file (GSF) is closed when you are using the device driver to send graphics output to a hard copy device.

arguments.name: DRIVERTERM
arguments.description: closes the GSF and makes it available to the device after all graphs have been produced and the procedure or driver terminates.

arguments.name: GRAPHEND
arguments.description: closes the GSF after each separate graph is produced and releases it to the device before sending another.

arguments.name: FILEONLY
arguments.description: specifies that a file rather than a storage location is the default destination for graphics output.

arguments.name: FILL
arguments.description: causes SAS/GRAPH to use the built-in hardware rectangle-filling capability of the device.

arguments.name: FILLINC=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of pixels to move before drawing the next line in a software fill of a solid area.

arguments.name: FONTRES=
arguments.description: Controls the resolution of Bitstream fonts.

arguments.name: NORMAL
arguments.description: renders fonts in memory using integer rendering routines, which improves character drawing speed for most host systems.

arguments.name: PRESENTATION
arguments.description: disables the storage or use of rendered versions of Bitstream fonts, but produces the fonts at their highest resolution.

arguments.name: FTEXT=
arguments.description: Sets the default font for all text.

arguments.name: text-font
arguments.description: specifies the font for all text on the graphics output.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: specifies that the default device-resident font be used for all text on the graphics output, if possible.

arguments.name: FTITLE=
arguments.description: Selects the default font for the first TITLE line.

arguments.name: title-font
arguments.description: specifies the font for the TITLE1 statement.

arguments.name: FTRACK=
arguments.description: Controls the amount of space between letters in the Bitstream fonts supplied by SAS (Brush, Century, Swiss, and Zapf).
arguments.help: FTRACK= LOOSE | NONE | NORMAL | TIGHT | TOUCH | V5

arguments.name: LOOSE
arguments.description: leaves the most visible space between characters and produces a longer string.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: spacing depends on the size of the font.

arguments.name: NORMAL
arguments.description: is the recommended setting.

arguments.name: TIGHT
arguments.description: reduces the space between characters.

arguments.name: TOUCH
arguments.description: leaves the least visible space between characters.

arguments.name: V5
arguments.description: places a fixed amount of space between the characters and does not adjust for the shape of the character.

arguments.name: GACCESS=
arguments.description: Specifies the format or the destination or both of graphics data written to a traditional SAS/GRAPH device driver or to a graphics stream file (GSF).

arguments.name: SASGASTD
arguments.description: specifies that a continuous stream of data is written.

arguments.name: SASGAEDT
arguments.description: specifies that the file be host-specific edit format.

arguments.name: SASGAFIX
arguments.description: specifies that fixed-length records be written.

arguments.name: SASGALOG
arguments.description: specifies that records are to be written to the SAS log.

arguments.name: GSASFILE
arguments.description: specifies that the records are to be written to the destination whose fileref is GSASFILE.

arguments.name: 'output-format
arguments.description: specifies the destination in addition to one of these output format values: SASGASTD, SASGAEDT, or SASGAFIX.

arguments.name: GCOPIES=
arguments.description: Sets the current and maximum number of copies to be printed.

arguments.name: current-copies
arguments.description: specifies the current number of copies as an integer in the range 0–max-copies.

arguments.name: GEND=
arguments.description: Appends an ASCII string to every graphics data record that is sent to a device or file.

arguments.name: 'string'
arguments.description: specifies the ASCII string to append to every graphics data record that is sent to a device or file.

arguments.name: GEPILOG=
arguments.description: Sends a string to a device or file after all graphics commands are sent.

arguments.name: 'string'
arguments.description: specifies the string to a device or file after all graphics commands are sent.

arguments.name: GOUTMODE=
arguments.description: Appends to or replaces the graphics output catalog.

arguments.name: APPEND
arguments.description: adds each new graph to the end of the current catalog.

arguments.name: REPLACE
arguments.description: replaces the contents of the catalog with the graph or graphs produced by a single procedure.

arguments.name: GPROLOG=
arguments.description: Sends a string to device or file before graphics commands are sent.

arguments.name: 'string'
arguments.description: specifies the string to a device or file before all graphics commands are sent.

arguments.name: GPROTOCOL=
arguments.description: Specifies the protocol module to use when routing output directly to a printer or creating a graphics stream file (GSF) to send to a device attached to your host by a protocol converter.

arguments.name: module-name
arguments.description: specifies the protocol module name.

arguments.name: GRAPHRC
arguments.description: allows a return code at procedure termination.

arguments.name: GSFLEN=
arguments.description: Controls the length of records written to the graphics stream file (GSF).

arguments.name: record-length
arguments.description: specifies the length of the records written by the driver to a GSF or to the device as an integer in the range 0–99999.

arguments.name: GSFMODE=
arguments.description: Specifies the disposition of records written to a graphics stream file (GSF) or to a device or communications port by the device driver.

arguments.name: APPEND
arguments.description: adds the records to the end of a GSF designated by the GACCESS= or GSFNAME= graphics option or device parameter.

arguments.name: PORT
arguments.description: sends the records to a device or communications port.

arguments.name: REPLACE
arguments.description: replaces the existing contents of a GSF designated by the GACCESS= or GSFNAME= graphics option or device parameter.

arguments.name: GSFNAME=
arguments.description: Specifies the fileref of the file or aggregate file location to which graphics stream file records are written.

arguments.name: fileref
arguments.description: specifies a fileref that points to the destination for the graphics stream file (GSF) output.

arguments.name: GSFPROMPT
arguments.description: Specifies whether to write prompt messages to the graphics stream file (GSF).

arguments.name: GSIZE=
arguments.description: Sets the number of lines of display used for graphics for devices whose displays can be divided into graphics and text areas.

arguments.name: lines
arguments.description: specifies the number of lines to be used for graphics.

arguments.name: GSTART=
arguments.description: Prefixes every record of graphics data sent to a device or file with a string of characters.

arguments.name: 'string'
arguments.description: specifies the string that prefixes every record of graphics data sent to a device or file.

arguments.name: GUNIT=
arguments.description: Specifies the default unit of measure to use with height specifications.
arguments.help: GUNIT= CELLS | CM | IN | PCT | PT

arguments.name: CELLS
arguments.description: specifies character cells as the units.

arguments.name: CM
arguments.description: specifies centimeters as the units.

arguments.name: IN
arguments.description: specifies inches as the units.

arguments.name: PCT
arguments.description: specifies percentage of the graphics output area as the units.

arguments.name: PT
arguments.description: specifies points as the units (there are approximately 72 points in an inch).

arguments.name: GWAIT=
arguments.description: Specifies the time between each graph displayed in a series.

arguments.name: seconds
arguments.description: specifies the number of seconds between graphs.

arguments.name: HANDSHAKE=
arguments.description: Specifies the type of flow control used to regulate the flow of data to a hard copy device.

arguments.name: HARDWARE
arguments.description: specifies that SAS/GRAPH instruct the device to use the hardware CTS and RTS signals for flow control.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: specifies that SAS/GRAPH send data without providing flow control.

arguments.name: SOFTWARE
arguments.description: specifies that SAS/GRAPH use programmed flow control with plotters in eavesdrop mode.

arguments.name: XONXOFF
arguments.description: specifies that SAS/GRAPH instruct the device to use ASCII characters DC1 and DC3 for flow control.

arguments.name: HBY=
arguments.description: Specifies the height of BY lines generated when you use BY-group processing.

arguments.name: By
arguments.description: specifies the height of BY line text; by default By line-height is 1.

arguments.name: units
arguments.description: specifies the units.

arguments.name: HORIGIN=
arguments.description: Sets the horizontal offset from the lower left corner of the display area to the lower left corner of the graph.

arguments.name: horizontal-offset
arguments.description: specifies the horizontal offset as a nonnegative integer optionally followed by a units specification of IN for inches (default), CM for centimeters, or PT for points.

arguments.name: INCMPT
arguments.description: specifies the units as inches (IN), centimeters (CM), or points (PT).

arguments.name: HPOS=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of columns in the graphics output area.

arguments.name: columns
arguments.description: specifies the number of columns in the graphics output area, which is equivalent to the number of hardware characters that can be displayed horizontally.

arguments.name: HSIZE=
arguments.description: Sets the horizontal size of the graphics output area.

arguments.name: horizontal-size
arguments.description: specifies the width of the graphics output area as a positive number optionally followed by a units specification of IN for inches (default), CM for centimeters, or PT for points.

arguments.name: INCMPT
arguments.description: specifies the units as inches (IN), centimeters (CM), or points (PT).

arguments.name: HTEXT=
arguments.description: Specifies the default height of the text in the graphics output.

arguments.name: text-height
arguments.description: specifies the height of the text.

arguments.name: units
arguments.description: specifies the units.

arguments.name: HTITLE=
arguments.description: Selects the default height used for the first TITLE line.

arguments.name: title-height
arguments.description: specifies the height of the text in the TITLE1 statement.

arguments.name: units
arguments.description: specifies the units.

arguments.name: IBACK=
arguments.description: Specifies an image file to display in a graph's background area.

arguments.name: fileref
arguments.description: specifies a fileref that points to the image file that you want to use.

arguments.name: external-file
arguments.description: specifies the complete filename of the image file that you want to use.

arguments.name: URL
arguments.description: specifies the URL of the image file that you want to use.
suppresses a background image.

arguments.name: IMAGEPRINT
arguments.description: default value specifies that any images are to be included in graphics output.

arguments.name: IMAGESTYLE=
arguments.description: Specifies how to display the image file that is specified on the IBACK= option.

arguments.name: TILE
arguments.description: tile the image within the specified area.

arguments.name: FIT
arguments.description: fit the image within the background area.

arguments.name: INTERLACED
arguments.description: Specifies whether images are to be displayed as they are received in the browser.

arguments.name: INTERPOL=
arguments.description: Sets the default interpolation value for the SYMBOL statement.

arguments.name: interpolation-method
arguments.description: specifies the default interpolation to be used when the INTERPOL= option is not specified in the SYMBOL statement.

arguments.name: ITERATION=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of times to repeat the GIF or SVG animation loop.
specifies that the animation loops continuously.

arguments.name: iteration-count
arguments.description: specifies the number of times that the animation loop is repeated.

arguments.name: KEYMAP=
arguments.description: Selects the key map to use.

arguments.name: key-map-name
arguments.description: specifies the name of a key map.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: suppresses the key map assigned by default to a non-U.S. keyboard.

arguments.name: LFACTOR=
arguments.description: Selects the default hardware line thickness.

arguments.name: line-thickness-factor
arguments.description: specifies the default hardware line thickness as an integer in the range 0–9999.

arguments.name: NOACCESSIBLE
arguments.description: toggles off the ACCESSIBLE option.

arguments.name: NOALTDESC
arguments.description: toggles off the ALTDESC option.

arguments.name: NOAUTOCOPY
arguments.description: suppresses printing a copy of the graph.

arguments.name: NOAUTOFEED
arguments.description: suppresses the automatic paper feed.

arguments.name: NOBORDER
arguments.description: suppresses the border around the graphics output area.

arguments.name: NOCELL
arguments.description: suppresses cell alignment, causing the procedure to use the entire procedure output area and place axis and tick mark labels without regard to cell alignment.

arguments.name: NOCHARACTERS
arguments.description: causes SAS/GRAPH to draw the characters using the SIMULATE font and suppresses the use of all device—resident fonts, regardless of values that you specify in other SAS statements.

arguments.name: NOCIRCLEARC
arguments.description: causes SAS/GRAPH to use software move and draw commands to draw circles and arcs.

arguments.name: NOCOLLATE
arguments.description: Specifies whether to collate the output, if collation is supported by the device.

arguments.name: NODASH
arguments.description: causes SAS/GRAPH to draw the dashed lines.

arguments.name: NODISPLAY
arguments.description: suppresses the graph output.

arguments.name: NODUPLEX
arguments.description: specifies that duplex printing is not to be used.

arguments.name: NOERASE
arguments.description: causes the graph to remain on the display when you press Enter after the graph has been displayed.

arguments.name: NOFASTTEXT
arguments.description: specifies that integer-based font processing is not to be used.

arguments.name: NOFILEONLY
arguments.description: specifies that a storage location is the default destination for graphics output, unless a file of the same name exists.

arguments.name: NOFILL
arguments.description: causes SAS/GRAPH to use software fills to fill rectangles.

arguments.name: NOGRAPHRC
arguments.description: always returns a step code of 0, even if the SAS/GRAPH program produced errors.

arguments.name: NOGSFPROMPT
arguments.description: Specifies whether to write prompt messages to the graphics stream file (GSF).

arguments.name: NOIMAGEPRINT
arguments.description: specifies that images are to be withheld from graphics output.

arguments.name: NONINTERLACED
arguments.description: Specifies whether images are to be displayed as they are received in the browser.

arguments.name: NOPCLIP
arguments.description: stores the unclipped form of the polygon and causes the polygon to be clipped when replayed.

arguments.name: NOPENSORT
arguments.description: causes the plotter to draw each element as it is encountered, regardless of its color.

arguments.name: NOPIEFILL
arguments.description: causes SAS/GRAPH to fill pies and pie sections using software pie fills.

arguments.name: NOPOLYGONCLIP
arguments.description: specifies line clipping; a polygon that has been line-clipped cannot use a hardware pattern.

arguments.name: NOPOLYGONFILL
arguments.description: causes SAS/GRAPH to use software fills to fill polygons.

arguments.name: NOPROMPT
arguments.description: suppresses all prompts. NOPROMPT overrides the GWAIT= graphics option.

arguments.name: NOQMSG
arguments.description: prevents the queuing of messages (default for plotters, cameras, and printers).

arguments.name: NOREVERSE
arguments.description: Specifies whether to print the output in reverse order, if reverse printing is supported by the device.

arguments.name: NOROTATE
arguments.description: specifies no rotation.

arguments.name: NOSWAP
arguments.description: does not swap the colors.

arguments.name: NOSYMBOL
arguments.description: causes SAS/GRAPH to draw the symbols using SAS/GRAPH fonts.

arguments.name: NOTRANSPARENCY
arguments.description: Specifies whether the background of the image should appear to be transparent when the image is displayed in the browser.

arguments.name: NOUSERINPUT
arguments.description: disables user input

arguments.name: OFFSHADOW=
arguments.description: Controls the width and depth of the drop shadow in legend frames.

arguments.name: (xunits,yunits)
arguments.description: specify the width (x) with optional units and depth (y) with optional units of the drop shadow generated by the LEGEND statement.

arguments.name: (x,y units)
arguments.description: specify the width (x) and depth (y) with optional units of the drop shadow generated by the LEGEND statement.

arguments.name: PAPERDEST=
arguments.description: Specifies which output bin the printer should use if multiple bins are available on the device.

arguments.name: bin
arguments.description: specifies the name or number of the output bin.

arguments.name: 'long
arguments.description: specifies the name of the output bin as a character string.

arguments.name: PAPERFEED=
arguments.description: Specifies the increment of paper that is ejected when a graph is completed.

arguments.name: feed-increment
arguments.description: specifies the feed increment as a nonnegative number.

arguments.name: INCM
arguments.description: specifies the units as inches (IN) or centimeters (CM).

arguments.name: PAPERLIMIT=
arguments.description: Sets the width of the paper used with plotters.

arguments.name: width
arguments.description: specifies the paper width as a numeric value.

arguments.name: INCM
arguments.description: specifies the units as inches (IN) or centimeters (CM).

arguments.name: PAPERSIZE=
arguments.description: Specifies the name of a paper size.

arguments.name: size-name
arguments.description: specifies the name of a paper size, such as LETTER, LEGAL, or A4.

arguments.name: PAPERSOURCE=
arguments.description: Specifies which paper tray the printer should use if multiple trays are available on the device.

arguments.name: tray
arguments.description: specifies the name or number of the paper tray.

arguments.name: 'long
arguments.description: specifies the name of the paper tray as a character string.

arguments.name: PAPERTYPE=
arguments.description: Specifies the name of a paper type.

arguments.name: type-name
arguments.description: specifies the name of a paper type.

arguments.name: PCLIP
arguments.description: stores clipped polygons with the graph in the default catalog WORK.GSEG, or in the catalog that you specify.

arguments.name: PENMOUNTS=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of active pens or colors.

arguments.name: active-pen-mounts
arguments.description: specifies the number of pens for a plotter with multiple pens.

arguments.name: PENSORT
arguments.description: causes the plotter to draw all graphics elements of one color at one time.

arguments.name: PIEFILL
arguments.description: causes SAS/GRAPH to use the built-in hardware capability of the device, if available, to fill pies and pie sections.

arguments.name: POLYGONCLIP
arguments.description: specifies polygon clipping, which enables a clipped polygon to be filled with a hardware pattern.

arguments.name: POLYGONFILL
arguments.description: causes SAS/GRAPH to use the built-in hardware capability of the device to fill polygons.

arguments.name: POSTGEPILOG=
arguments.description: Specifies data to send immediately after the data that is stored in the Gepilog field of the device entry is sent.

arguments.name: 'string'
arguments.description: specifies the data to send immediately after the data that is stored in the Gepilog field of the device entry is sent.

arguments.name: POSTGPROLOG=
arguments.description: Specifies the data to send immediately after the data that is stored in the Gprolog field of the device entry is sent.

arguments.name: 'string'
arguments.description: specifies the data to send immediately after the data that is stored in the Gprolog field of the device entry is sent.

arguments.name: POSTGRAPH1=
arguments.description: Specifies host commands to be executed after the graph is produced.

arguments.name: system-command
arguments.description: specifies one or more valid system commands.

arguments.name: POSTGRAPH2=
arguments.description: Specifies host commands to be executed after the graph is produced.

arguments.name: system-command
arguments.description: specifies one or more valid system commands.

arguments.name: PPDFILE=
arguments.description: Specifies the location of an external file containing PostScript Printer Description (PPD) information.

arguments.name: fileref
arguments.description: specifies a fileref that points to the PPD file that you want to use.

arguments.name: external-file
arguments.description: specifies the complete filename of the PPD file that you want to use.

arguments.name: PREGEPILOG=
arguments.description: Specifies data to send immediately before the data that is stored in the Gepilog field of the device entry is sent.

arguments.name: 'string'
arguments.description: specifies data to send immediately before the data that is stored in the Gepilog field of the device entry is sent.

arguments.name: PREGPROLOG=
arguments.description: Specifies the data to send immediately before the data that is stored in the Gprolog field of the device entry is sent.

arguments.name: 'string'
arguments.description: specifies the data to send immediately before the data that is stored in the Gprolog field of the device entry is sent.

arguments.name: PREGRAPH1=
arguments.description: Specifies host commands to be executed before the graph is produced.

arguments.name: system-command
arguments.description: specifies one or more valid system commands.

arguments.name: PREGRAPH2=
arguments.description: Specifies host commands to be executed before the graph is produced.

arguments.name: system-command
arguments.description: specifies one or more valid system commands.

arguments.name: PROMPT
arguments.description: causes all prompts to be displayed.

arguments.name: PROMPTCHARS=
arguments.description: Selects the prompt characters to be used by SAS/GRAPH device drivers.

arguments.name: prompt-chars-hex-string
arguments.description: specifies the prompt characters to be used by SAS/GRAPH device drivers as an 8-byte hexadecimal string that is specified as 16 hexadecimal characters.

arguments.name: QMSG
arguments.description: queues driver messages while the device is in graphics mode (default for video devices).

arguments.name: RENDER=
arguments.description: Controls the creation and disposition of rendered Bitstream fonts.
arguments.help: RENDER= APPEND | DISK | MEMORY | NONE | READ

arguments.name: APPEND
arguments.description: creates files to store rendered versions of Bitstream fonts if the files do not already exist, reads previously rendered characters from the font files, and appends rendered versions of new characters to the font files when the SAS/GRAPH procedure terminates.

arguments.name: DISK
arguments.description: creates files to store rendered versions of Bitstream fonts if the files do not already exist, reads previously rendered characters from the font files, and appends rendered versions of new characters to the font files as they are encountered.

arguments.name: MEMORY
arguments.description: renders all fonts in memory without creating any font files on disk.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: disables the font rendering features.

arguments.name: READ
arguments.description: reads existing rendered font files but does not create new font files or write new characters to existing font files.

arguments.name: RENDERLIB=
arguments.description: Specifies the SAS library in which rendered font files are stored.

arguments.name: libref
arguments.description: specifies a previously defined libref that identifies the SAS library.

arguments.name: REPAINT=
arguments.description: Specifies how many times to redraw the graph.

arguments.name: redraw-factor
arguments.description: specifies how many times to redraw the graph as a integer in the range 0–999.

arguments.name: RESET=
arguments.description: Resets graphics options to their default values, cancels global statements, or both.

arguments.name: ALL
arguments.description: sets all graphics options to defaults and cancels all global statements.

arguments.name: GLOBAL
arguments.description: cancels all global statements (AXIS, FOOTNOTE, LEGEND, PATTERN, SYMBOL, and TITLE).

arguments.name: statement-name
arguments.description: resets or cancels only the specified global statements.

arguments.name: REVERSE
arguments.description: Specifies whether to print the output in reverse order, if reverse printing is supported by the device.

arguments.name: ROTATE
arguments.description: specifies rotation of 90 degrees from the default graph orientation.

arguments.name: ROTATE=
arguments.description: Specifies whether and how to rotate the graph.

arguments.name: LANDSCAPE
arguments.description: specifies landscape orientation (the graph is wider than it is high).

arguments.name: PORTRAIT
arguments.description: specifies portrait orientation (the graph is higher than it is wide).

arguments.name: SIMFONT=
arguments.description: Specifies a SAS/GRAPH font to use if the default device-resident font cannot be used.

arguments.name: SAS/GRAPH-font
arguments.description: specifies a SAS/GRAPH font to use instead of the default device-resident font.

arguments.name: SPEED=
arguments.description: Selects pen speed for plotters with variable speed selection.

arguments.name: pen-speed
arguments.description: specifies a percentage (1 through 100) of the maximum pen speed for the device.

arguments.name: SWAP
arguments.description: swaps BLACK for WHITE and vice versa.

arguments.name: SWFONTRENDER=
arguments.description: Specifies the method used to render system fonts.

arguments.name: POLYGON
arguments.description: uses polygon rendering

arguments.name: SCANLINE
arguments.description: uses scanline rendering

arguments.name: SYMBOL
arguments.description: causes SAS/GRAPH to use the built-in symbol-drawing capability of the device, if available.

arguments.name: TARGETDEVICE=
arguments.description: Displays the output as it would appear on a different device. Also, specifies the device driver for the PRINT command.

arguments.name: target-device-entry
arguments.description: specifies the name of a device entry in a catalog.

arguments.name: TRANSPARENCY
arguments.description: Specifies whether the background of the image should appear to be transparent when the image is displayed in the browser.

arguments.name: TRANTAB=
arguments.description: Selects a translate table for your system that performs ASCII-to-EBCDIC translation.

arguments.name: table
arguments.description: specifies a translate table stored as a SAS/GRAPH catalog entry.

arguments.name: user-defined-table
arguments.description: specifies the name of a user-created translate table.

arguments.name: UCC=
arguments.description: Sets the user-defined control characters for the device.

arguments.name: control-characters-hex-string
arguments.description: specifies the user-defined control characters for the device as a hexadecimal string that can be up 32 bytes (64 characters) long.

arguments.name: USERINPUT
arguments.description: enables user input

arguments.name: VORIGIN=
arguments.description: Sets the vertical offset from the lower left corner of the display area to the lower left corner of the graph.

arguments.name: vertical-offset
arguments.description: specifies the vertical offset as a nonnegative number.

arguments.name: INCMPT
arguments.description: specifies the units as inches (IN), centimeters (CM), or points (PT).

arguments.name: VPOS=
arguments.description: Sets the number of rows in the graphics output area.

arguments.name: rows
arguments.description: specifies the number of rows in the graphics output area, which is equivalent to the number of hardware characters that can be displayed vertically.

arguments.name: VSIZE=
arguments.description: Sets the vertical size of the graphics output area.

arguments.name: vertical-size
arguments.description: specifies the height of the graphics output area as a positive number.

arguments.name: INCMPT
arguments.description: specifies the units as inches (IN), centimeters (CM), or points (PT).

arguments.name: XMAX=
arguments.description: Specifies the width of the addressable graphics display area; affects the horizontal resolution of the device and the horizontal dimension of the graphics output area.

arguments.name: width
arguments.description: specifies the width of the addressable graphics display area as a positive number.

arguments.name: INCMPT
arguments.description: specifies the units as inches (IN), centimeters (CM), or points (PT).

arguments.name: XPIXELS=
arguments.description: Specifies the width of the addressable display area in pixels and in conjunction with XMAX determines the horizontal resolution for the device.

arguments.name: width-in-pixels
arguments.description: specifies the width of the addressable display area in pixels as an integer in the range 0–99999999.

arguments.name: YMAX=
arguments.description: Specifies the height of the addressable graphics display area; affects the vertical resolution of the device and the vertical dimension of the graphics output area.

arguments.name: height
arguments.description: specifies the height of the addressable graphics display area as a positive number optionally followed by a units specification of IN for inches (default), CM for centimeters, or PT for points.

arguments.name: INCMPT
arguments.description: specifies the units as inches (IN), centimeters (CM), or points (PT).

arguments.name: YPIXELS=
arguments.description: Specifies the height of the addressable display area in pixels and in conjunction with YMAX determines the horizontal resolution for the device.

arguments.name: height-in-pixels
arguments.description: specifies the height of the addressable display area in pixels as an integer in the range 0–99999999.

name: LEGEND
description: Controls the location and appearance of legends on maps.

arguments.name: ACROSS=
arguments.description: specifies the number of columns to use for legend entries.

arguments.name: CBLOCK=
arguments.description: generates and colors a three-dimensional block effect behind the legend.

arguments.name: CBORDER=
arguments.description: draws a colored frame around the legend.

arguments.name: CFRAME=
arguments.description: specifies the background color of the legend.

arguments.name: CSHADOW=
arguments.description: generates and colors a drop shadow behind the legend.

arguments.name: DOWN=
arguments.description: specifies the number of rows to use for legend entries.

arguments.name: FRAME
arguments.description: draws a frame around the legend.

arguments.name: NOFRAME
arguments.description: draws a frame around the legend.

arguments.name: FWIDTH=
arguments.description: specifies the thickness of the frame, where thickness-factor is a number.

arguments.name: LABEL=
arguments.description: modifies a legend label.

arguments.name: ANGLE=
arguments.description: specifies the angle of the legend label or legend value description text with respect to the horizontal. A positive value for degrees moves the text counterclockwise; a negative value moves it clockwise. By default, ANGLE=0 (horizontal).

arguments.name: COLOR=
arguments.description: specifies the color of the text. If you omit the COLOR= option, a color specification is searched for in this order:

arguments.name: FONT=
arguments.description: specifies the font for the text. See for information about specifying fonts. If you omit the FONT= option, a font specification is searched for in this order:

arguments.name: HEIGHT=
arguments.description: specifies the height of the text characters in the number of units. By default, HEIGHT=1 CELL. If you omit the HEIGHT= option, a text height specification is searched for in this order:

arguments.name: JUSTIFY=
arguments.description: specifies the alignment of the text. The default for character variables is JUSTIFY=LEFT. The default for numeric variables is JUSTIFY=RIGHT. Associating a character format with a numeric variable does not change the default justification of the variable.

arguments.name: LEFT
arguments.description: aligns the text to the left.

arguments.name: CENTER
arguments.description: aligns the text in the center.

arguments.name: RIGHT
arguments.description: aligns the text to the right.

arguments.name: POSITION=
arguments.description: places the legend label in relation to the legend entries. The POSITION= option is used only with the LABEL= option. By default, POSITION=LEFT.

arguments.name: ROTATE=
arguments.description: specifies the angle at which each character of text is rotated with respect to the baseline of the text string. A positive value for degree rotates the character counterclockwise; a negative value moves it clockwise. By default, ROTATE=0 (parallel to the baseline).

arguments.name: TICK=
arguments.description: specifies the nth legend entry. The TICK= option is used only with the VALUE= option to designate the legend entry whose text and appearance you want to modify. For example, to change the text of the third legend entry to Minneapolis, specify the following code:

arguments.name: "text-string"
arguments.description: provides up to 256 characters of label text. Enclose each string in quotation marks. Separate multiple strings with blanks.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: suppresses the value descriptions.

arguments.name: MODE=
arguments.description: specifies whether the legend is drawn in the procedure output area or whether legend elements can overlay other graphics elements.

arguments.name: PROTECT
arguments.description: draws the legend in the procedure output area, but a blanking area surrounds the legend, preventing other graphics elements from being displayed in the legend. (A blanking area is a protected area in which no other graphics elements are displayed.)

arguments.name: RESERVE
arguments.description: takes space for the legend from the procedure output area, thereby reducing the amount of space available for the graph. If MODE=RESERVE is specified in conjunction with OFFSET=, the legend can push the graph off the graphics output area. RESERVE is valid only when POSITION=OUTSIDE. If POSITION=INSIDE is specified, a warning is issued and MODE= value is changed to PROTECT.

arguments.name: SHARE
arguments.description: draws the legend in the procedure output area. If the legend is positioned over elements of the graph itself, both graphics elements and legend elements are displayed.

arguments.name: OFFSET=
arguments.description: specifies the distance to move the entire legend.

arguments.name: ORDER=
arguments.description: selects or orders the legend values that appear in the legend.

arguments.name: ORIGIN=
arguments.description: specifies the x and y coordinates of the lower left corner of the legend box.

arguments.name: POSITION=
arguments.description: positions the legend on the graph.
arguments.help: POSITION=(<BOTTOM | MIDDLE | TOP> <LEFT | CENTER | RIGHT> <OUTSIDE | INSIDE>)

arguments.name: OUTSIDE
arguments.description: specifies the location of the legend in relation to the axis area.

arguments.name: INSIDE
arguments.description: specifies the location of the legend in relation to the axis area.

arguments.name: BOTTOM
arguments.description: specifies the vertical position.

arguments.name: MIDDLE
arguments.description: specifies the vertical position.

arguments.name: TOP
arguments.description: specifies the vertical position.

arguments.name: LEFT
arguments.description: specifies the horizontal position.

arguments.name: CENTER
arguments.description: specifies the horizontal position.

arguments.name: RIGHT
arguments.description: specifies the horizontal position.

arguments.name: REPEAT=
arguments.description: specifies how many times the plot symbol is repeated in the legend.

arguments.name: ROWMAJOR
arguments.description: specifies the arrangement of legend entries when there are multiple rows and multiple columns.

arguments.name: COLMAJOR
arguments.description: specifies the arrangement of legend entries when there are multiple rows and multiple columns.

arguments.name: SHAPE=
arguments.description: specifies the size and shape of the legend values displayed in each legend entry.

arguments.name: BAR
arguments.description: is used with the GMAP procedure. Each legend value is a bar of the specified width and height.

arguments.name: (widthunits,heightunits) units
arguments.description: is used with the GMAP procedure. Each legend value is a bar of the specified width and height.

arguments.name: LINE
arguments.description: is used with the GPLOT and GCONTOUR procedures. Each legend value is a line of the length that you specify. Plotting symbols are omitted from the legend values. You can specify units for length.

arguments.name: SYMBOL
arguments.description: is used with the GPLOT procedure. Each legend value (not each symbol), is the width and height that you specify. For example, this specification produces legend values like the ones in (a):

arguments.name: (widthunits,heightunits) units
