arguments.description: specifies use of an IN clause that contains values that were read from a smaller table. The clause is used to retrieve matching values in a larger table based on a key column that was designated in an equijoin.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: turns off option functionality.

arguments.name: MUTUAL_AUTH=
arguments.description: Specifies whether to enforce mutual authentication.

arguments.name: YES
arguments.description: Specifies that mutual authentication is enabled. This requires that both the SAS client and the Salesforce server must authenticate each other's identities using a mutual authentication certificate. To do this, you must set the path to your local certificate (CERT_PATH=) and a password (CERT_PASS).

arguments.name: NO
arguments.description: Specifies that mutual authentication is disabled. By default, the Salesforce engine connects to port 4443 through a secured connection over HTTPS.

arguments.name: MYSQL
arguments.description: specifies the SAS/ACCESS engine name for MySQL interface.

arguments.name: NAMESPACE=
arguments.description: Subsets a table list by namespace.

arguments.name: NETCOMP=
arguments.description: Sends compressed data in a server network packet.

arguments.name: NETEZZA
arguments.description: specifies the SAS/ACCESS engine name for the Netezza interface.

arguments.name: NEWPASSWORD=
arguments.description: Specifies a new password for an SPD Server user.

arguments.name: NOPROMPT=
arguments.description: specifies connection options for your database. Separate multiple options with a semicolon. If you do not specify enough correct connection options, an error is returned.

arguments.name: NUMC_SAS_TYPE=
arguments.description: Indicates the SAS type for ABAP type NUMC.

arguments.name: ODBC
arguments.description: specifies the SAS/ACCESS engine name for the ODBC interface.

arguments.name: ODSCHARSET=
arguments.description: Specifies the character set to use for the output file

arguments.name: character-set
arguments.description: specifies the character set to use for the output file.

arguments.name: ODSRECSEP=
arguments.description: Controls the generation of a record separator that marks the end of a line in the output XML document.

arguments.name: DEFAULT
arguments.description: enables the XML engine to determine whether to generate a record separator based on the operating environment where you run the SAS job.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: specifies to not generate a record separator.

arguments.name: YES
arguments.description: specifies to generate a record separator.

arguments.name: ODSTRANTAB=
arguments.description: Specifies the translation table to use for the output file.

arguments.name: table-name
arguments.description: specifies the translation table to use for the output file.

arguments.name: ORACLE
arguments.description: specifies the SAS/ACCESS engine name for the Oracle interface.

arguments.name: ORC
arguments.description: specifies the ORC LIBNAME engine.

arguments.name: OR_
arguments.description: Specifies the default data type to use for numeric table columns.

arguments.name: YES
arguments.description: specifies BINARY_DOUBLE as the default.

arguments.name: NO
arguments.description: specifies NUMBER as the default.

arguments.name: OR_ENABLE_INTERRUPT=
arguments.description: Allows interruption of any long-running SQL processes on the DBMS server.

arguments.name: YES
arguments.description: allows interruption of long-running SQL processes on the DBMS server.

arguments.name: NO
arguments.description: disables interruption of long-running SQL processes on the DBMS server.

arguments.name: OR_UPD_NOWHERE=
arguments.description: Specifies whether SAS uses an extra WHERE clause when updating rows with no locking.

arguments.name: YES
arguments.description: specifies that SAS does not use an additional WHERE clause to determine whether each row has changed since it was read. Instead, SAS uses the SERIALIZABLE isolation level (available with Oracle7.3 and above) for update locking. If a row changes after the serializable transaction starts, the update on that row fails.

arguments.name: NO
arguments.description: specifies that SAS uses an additional WHERE clause to determine whether each row has changed since it was read. If a row has changed since being read, the update fails.

arguments.name: PACKETSIZE=
arguments.description: Allows specification of the packet size for SAP ASE to use.

arguments.name: numeric-value
arguments.description: any multiple of 512, up to the limit of the maximum network packet size value on your server.

arguments.name: PARMDEFAULT=
arguments.description: Specifies whether the SAP HANA engine uses the defaults for variables and parameters that are specified in the metadata in SAP HANA.

arguments.name: YES
arguments.description: specifies to look up metadata for variables and parameters. This enables you to apply defaults for variables in a WHERE clause, and defaults for input parameters using the PLACEHOLDER syntax.

arguments.name: NO
arguments.description: specifies to not look up metadata for variables and parameters.

arguments.name: PARMSTRING=
arguments.description: Specifies a quoted string of variable name and value pairs separated by a comma, or a placeholder string.

arguments.name: "variable-name1=
arguments.description: specifies the variable name and value pair. More than one pair can be specified and must be separated by a comma.

arguments.name: "'PLACEHOLDER'
arguments.description: specifies the variable name and value pair as a placeholder.

arguments.name: PARQUET
arguments.description: specifies the Parquet LIBNAME engine.

arguments.name: PARTSIZE=
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum size (in megabytes, gigabytes, or terabytes) that the data component partitions can be. The value is specified when an SPD Engine data set is created. This size is a fixed size. This specification applies only to the data component files.

arguments.name: n
arguments.description: is the size of the partition in megabytes, gigabytes, or terabytes. If n is specified without M, G, or T, the default is megabytes. PARTSIZE=128 is the same as PARTSIZE=128M. The maximum value is 8,796,093,022,207 megabytes.

arguments.name: M
arguments.description: is the size of the partition in megabytes, gigabytes, or terabytes. If n is specified without M, G, or T, the default is megabytes. PARTSIZE=128 is the same as PARTSIZE=128M. The maximum value is 8,796,093,022,207 megabytes.

arguments.name: G
arguments.description: is the size of the partition in megabytes, gigabytes, or terabytes. If n is specified without M, G, or T, the default is megabytes. PARTSIZE=128 is the same as PARTSIZE=128M. The maximum value is 8,796,093,022,207 megabytes.

arguments.name: T
arguments.description: is the size of the partition in megabytes, gigabytes, or terabytes. If n is specified without M, G, or T, the default is megabytes. PARTSIZE=128 is the same as PARTSIZE=128M. The maximum value is 8,796,093,022,207 megabytes.

arguments.name: PASSWORD=
arguments.description: specifies the password or access token. The USER= and PASSWORD= options remain valid. However, these options are less secure because you are saving authentication information in your programs. Therefore, as a better security practice, it is recommended that you use the AUTHDOMAIN= option instead.

arguments.name: PATH=
arguments.description: specifies the Oracle driver, node, and database. Aliases are required if you are using SQL*Net Version 2.0 or later. In some operating environments, you can enter the information that is required by the PATH= statement before invoking SAS.

arguments.name: PCFILES
arguments.description: is the LIBNAME engine running on Linux to read and write Microsoft Excel and Microsoft Access files on the SAS PC Files Server.

arguments.name: PLATFORM=
arguments.description: specifies the target platform.

arguments.name: PORT=
arguments.description: specifies the port number for building the JDBC URL connection string. This option is ignored when the URL= option is specified.

arguments.name: POSTGRES
arguments.description: specifies the SAS/ACCESS engine name for the PostgreSQL interface.

arguments.name: POST_DML_STMT_OPTS=
arguments.description: Specifies text to append to an INSERT, UPDATE, or DELETE statement.

arguments.name: value
arguments.description: specifies text to append to an UPDATE, INSERT, or DELETE statement. SAS/ACCESS does not verify the validity of the text that you provide.

arguments.name: POST_STMT_OPTS=
arguments.description: Allows additional database-specific options to be placed after the CREATE TABLE statement in generated SQL code.

arguments.name: DBMS-SQL-option
arguments.description: specifies database-specific options to be placed after the CREATE TABLE statement. Enclose the options that you specify within single or double quotation marks.

arguments.name: PREFETCH=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of cached rowsets to be used by client and server prefetching.
arguments.help: PREFETCH= 0  | OFF | FALSE | NO | 1 | ON | TRUE | YES | *unsigned-integer*

arguments.name: PREFETCHBYTES=
arguments.description: Modifies the size of the cached rowsets used in prefetching.

arguments.name: PREFETCHROWS=
arguments.description: Modifies the number of rows in the cached rowsets used in prefetching.

arguments.name: PREFIXATTRIBUTES=
arguments.description: Specifies whether the element name is concatenated to the attribute name when generating each XMLMap COLUMN element, which defines the SAS variable name.

arguments.name: YES
arguments.description: specifies that the element name is attached to the resulting SAS variable name.

arguments.name: NO
arguments.description: specifies that the element name is not attached to the resulting SAS variable name.

arguments.name: PRESERVE_COL_NAMES=
arguments.description: Specifies whether to preserve spaces, special characters, and case sensitivity in DBMS column names when you create DBMS tables.

arguments.name: YES
arguments.description: specifies that column names that are used in table creation are passed to the DBMS with special characters and the exact, case-sensitive spelling of the name is preserved.

arguments.name: NO
arguments.description: specifies that column names that are used to create DBMS tables are derived from SAS variable names (VALIDVARNAME= system option) by using the SAS variable name normalization rules. However, the database applies its DBMS-specific normalization rules to the SAS variable names when creating the DBMS column names.

arguments.name: PRESERVE_COMMENTS=
arguments.description: Specifies whether comments should be kept and passed down to your data source for processing.

arguments.name: YESNO
arguments.description: specifies whether comments should be passed down to your data source.

arguments.name: PRESERVE_NAMES=
arguments.description: Specifies whether to preserve spaces, special characters, and case sensitivity in DBMS column names and table names.

arguments.name: YES
arguments.description: specifies that column names and table names are preserved, according to the rules for PRESERVE_COL_NAMES=YES and PRESERVE_TAB_NAMES=YES.

arguments.name: NO
arguments.description: specifies that column names and table names are not preserved, according to the rules for PRESERVE_COL_NAMES=NO and PRESERVE_TAB_NAMES=NO.

arguments.name: PRESERVE_TAB_NAMES=
arguments.description: Specifies whether to preserves spaces, special characters, and case sensitivity in DBMS table names.

arguments.name: YES
arguments.description: specifies that table names are read from and passed to the DBMS with special characters, and the exact, case-sensitive spelling of the name is preserved.

arguments.name: NO
arguments.description: specifies that when you create DBMS tables or refer to an existing table, the table names are derived from SAS member names by using SAS member name normalization. However, the database applies DBMS-specific normalization rules to the SAS member names. Therefore, the table names are created or referenced in the database following the DBMS-specific normalization rules.

arguments.name: PRESERVE_USER=
arguments.description: Preserves the case of the value in the USER= connection option.

arguments.name: YES
arguments.description: specifies that SAS/ACCESS preserves the case of the value for the USER= option.

arguments.name: NO
arguments.description: specifies that SAS/ACCESS changes the value for the USER= option to uppercase for use in later connections.

arguments.name: PROC_DATASETS_TAGFILTER=
arguments.description: Specifies a character string, which can include the wildcard characters ‘*’ and ‘?’, that is used to limit the output from the DATASETS procedure.

arguments.name: filter-string
arguments.description: specifies a character string that is used to limit the output from the DATASETS procedure. The character string can contain these wildcard characters:

arguments.name: PROGRAM_NAME=

arguments.name: QUERY_TIMEOUT=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of seconds of inactivity to wait before canceling a query.

arguments.name: number-of-seconds
arguments.description: specifies a positive integer for the number of seconds to wait before canceling the query. The default value of 0 indicates that there is no time limit for a query. This option is useful when you are testing a query or if you suspect that a query might contain an endless loop.

arguments.name: QUOTED_IDENTIFIER=
arguments.description: Allows specification of table and column names with embedded spaces and special characters.

arguments.name: QUOTE_CHAR=
arguments.description: Specifies which quotation mark character to use when delimiting identifiers.

arguments.name: character

arguments.name: R3
arguments.description: explicitly specifies the R/3 library engine.

arguments.name: R3NAME=
arguments.description: Indicates the name of the R/3 system.

arguments.name: READBUFF=
aliases:
ROWSET_SIZE= [Amazon Redshift, DB2,
         Greenplum, Impala, Informix, Microsoft SQL Server, Netezza, ODBC, PostgreSQL, SAP ASE, SAP
         HANA, SAP IQ, Vertica]
arguments.description: Specifies the number of rows of DBMS data to read into the buffer.

arguments.name: integer
arguments.description: the positive number of rows to hold in memory. SAS allows the maximum number that the DBMS allows.

arguments.name: READTRANSFERSIZE=
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum number of bytes that the CAS engine reads when transferring data from the CAS server.

arguments.name: READ_EXPOSURE_OK=
arguments.description: Specifies whether the SAS/ACCESS engine functions like a random access engine for the scope of the LIBNAME statement.

arguments.name: YES
arguments.description: specifies that the SAS/ACCESS engine functions like a random access engine when rereading a row so that you cannot guarantee that the same row is returned. For example, if you read row 5 and someone else deletes it, you read a different row the next time you read row 5. You have the potential for data integrity exposures within the scope of your SAS session.

arguments.name: NO
arguments.description: specifies that the SAS/ACCESS engine functions as a sequential engine with some limited random access capabilites. In this case, your data is protected by the normal data protection that SAS provides.

arguments.name: READ_ISOLATION_LEVEL=
arguments.description: Specifies the degree of isolation of the current application process from other concurrently running application processes.

arguments.name: READ_LOCK_TYPE=
arguments.description: Specifies how data in a DBMS table is locked during a READ transaction.
arguments.help:
READ_LOCK_TYPE= ROW | 
                                        PAGE | 
                                        TABLE | 
                                        NOLOCK | 
                                        VIEW

arguments.name: ROW
arguments.description: locks a row if any of its columns are accessed. If you are using the interface to ODBC or DB2, READ_LOCK_TYPE=ROW indicates that locking is based on the READ_ISOLATION_LEVEL= LIBNAME option.

arguments.name: PAGE
arguments.description: locks a page of data, which is a DBMS-specific number of bytes.

arguments.name: TABLE
arguments.description: locks the entire DBMS table. If you specify READ_LOCK_TYPE=TABLE, you must also specify CONNECTION=UNIQUE, or you receive an error message. Specifying CONNECTION=UNIQUE ensures that your table lock is not lost (for example, due to another table closing and committing rows in the same connection).

arguments.name: NOLOCK
arguments.description: does not lock the DBMS table, pages, or rows during a read transaction.

arguments.name: VIEW
arguments.description: locks the entire DBMS view.

arguments.name: READ_METHOD=
arguments.description: Specifies how to read data.

arguments.name: JDBC
arguments.description: specifies that data is to be read through the JDBC connection to the Hive service. You can use the ANALYZE= option to potentially improve performance when querying small tables.

arguments.name: HDFS
arguments.description: specifies that data is to be read through a connection to the Hadoop HDFS service.

arguments.name: READ_MODE=
arguments.description: Specifies the method to use to move data into SAS.

arguments.name: STANDARDSTORAGE
arguments.description: specifies the method to use when moving data from Google BigQuery into SAS.

arguments.name: READ_MODE_WAIT=
arguments.description: During SAS/ACCESS Read operations, specifies whether Teradata should wait to acquire a lock or fail the request when a different user has already locked the DBMS resource.

arguments.name: YES
arguments.description: specifies for Teradata to wait to acquire the lock, so SAS/ACCESS waits indefinitely until it can acquire the lock.

arguments.name: NO
arguments.description: specifies Teradata fails the lock request if the specified DBMS resource is locked.

arguments.name: READ_ONLY=
arguments.description: specifies whether to connect to the Netezza database in Read-Only mode (YES) or read-write (NO) mode. I

arguments.name: REDSHIFT
arguments.description: specifies the SAS/ACCESS engine name for the Amazon Redshift interface.

arguments.name: REFRESH_TOKEN=
arguments.description: Specifies the refresh token value for the OAuth client that is used to connect to Google BigQuery using the OAuth authentication method.

arguments.name: token-value
arguments.description: specifies the refresh token value for the OAuth client that is used to connect to Google BigQuery using the OAuth authentication method.

arguments.name: REMOTE_DRIVER=
arguments.description: Specifies the remote driver to use for the SAS Federation Server connection.
arguments.help: REMOTE_DRIVER= REMFS | FSNET | IOM | FEDSVR | REMTS

arguments.name: REMOTE_DRIVER_OPTIONS=
arguments.description: Specifies remote driver options for connecting to Cloud Data Exchange for the SAS Viya platform.

arguments.name: "connection-option
arguments.description: one or more remote driver connection options, specified as option=value pairs and separated by a semicolon (;). For valid options, see .

arguments.name: REPEMPTY=
arguments.description: Controls replacement of a data set when the new data set is empty.

arguments.name: YES
arguments.description: specifies that a new, empty data set can replace an existing data set with the same name.

arguments.name: NO
arguments.description: specifies that a new, empty data set cannot replace an existing data set with the same name.

arguments.name: REREAD_EXPOSURE=
arguments.description: Specifies whether the SAS/ACCESS engine functions like a random access engine for the scope of the LIBNAME statement.

arguments.name: YES
arguments.description: specifies that the SAS/ACCESS engine functions like a random access engine when rereading a row so that you cannot guarantee that the same row is returned. For example, if you read row 5 and someone else deletes it, you read a different row the next time you read row 5. You have the potential for data integrity exposures within the scope of your SAS session.

arguments.name: NO
arguments.description: specifies that the SAS/ACCESS engine functions as a sequential engine with some limited random access capabilites. In this case, your data is protected by the normal data protection that SAS provides.

arguments.name: RESULTS=
arguments.description: Determines how result sets are retrieved from the server.

arguments.name: MEMORY
arguments.description: stores query results in client memory.

arguments.name: SERVER
arguments.description: stores query results on the server.

arguments.name: RFC_STRING=
arguments.description: Indicates additional logon or connection parameters for the RfcOpenEx() call.

arguments.name: ROLE=
arguments.description: specifies the default Snowflake role to use for sessions that the driver initiated. The specified role should be one that has been assigned to the specified user. If the specified role does not match any roles that are assigned to the user, sessions that the driver initiated have no role initially. However, a role can always be specified from within the session.

arguments.name: ROWSET_SIZE=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of rows of DBMS data to read into the buffer.

arguments.name: integer
arguments.description: specifies the number of rows to hold in memory. SAS allows the maximum value that is supported by the DBMS.

arguments.name: SAPASE
arguments.description: the SAS/ACCESS engine name for the SAP ASE interface.

arguments.name: SAPHANA

arguments.name: SAPIQ

arguments.name: SASEDOC
arguments.description: specifies the engine that associates a SAS libref (library reference) with one or more ODS output objects that are stored in an ODS document.

arguments.name: SASESOCK
arguments.description: identifies the SASESOCK engine to process input to and output from a TCP/IP port instead of a physical disk device.

arguments.name: SAS_DBMS_AUTOMETADATA=
arguments.description: Specifies whether to transfer data types and character-set metadata from input to output for DATA step processing.

arguments.name: SCAN_LIMIT=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of documents to scan to define or update a schema.

arguments.name: value
arguments.description: specifies the number of documents to scan to define or update a schema. The most recent documents are scanned first.

arguments.name: SCHEMA=
arguments.description: specifies the schema to use for sessions that the driver initiated.

arguments.name: SCHEMA_AUTH=
arguments.description: Specifies the authorization method that is used to access a MongoDB schema.

arguments.name: AUTO
arguments.description: specifies that SAS uses the default method of USER= and PWD= authentication to access a MongoDB schema.

arguments.name: KERBEROS
arguments.description: specifies that Kerberos authentication is used to access MongoDB.

arguments.name: LDAP
arguments.description: specifies that LDAP authentication is used to access a MongoDB schema.

arguments.name: PASSWORD
arguments.description: specifies that USER= and PWD= values are used to access a MongoDB schema.

arguments.name: SCHEMA_COLLECTION=
arguments.description: Specifies the MongoDB collection where the schema file is stored.

arguments.name: collection-name
arguments.description: specifies the MongoDB collection where the schema file is stored. If the schema file does not already exist, SAS/ACCESS scans the specified collection and stores the generated schema with the collection.

arguments.name: SCHEMA_DB=
arguments.description: Specifies the MongoDB database where a schema is stored.

arguments.name: database-name
arguments.description: specifies the MongoDB database where a schema file is stored.

arguments.name: SCHEMA_MONGO_PLATFORM=
arguments.description: Specifies the type of database server to use for the MongoDB schema mapping.

arguments.name: ATLAS
arguments.description: specifies that the MongoDB schema is stored in MongoDB Atlas. MongoDB Atlas replicates the schema file on all configured database server nodes.

arguments.name: NATIVE
arguments.description: specifies to store the MongoDB schema file on a local database server. In a MONGO_PLATFORM=ATLAS connection, there is no default server. Specify the location of the server by using the SCHEMA_DB=, SCHEMA_PORT=, and SCHEMA_SERVER= options.

arguments.name: SCHEMA_PASSWORD=
arguments.description: Specifies the password that corresponds to a schema.

arguments.name: string
arguments.description: specifies the password that corresponds to a schema.

arguments.name: SCHEMA_PORT=
arguments.description: Specifies the port that corresponds to a schema.

arguments.name: value
arguments.description: specifies the port that corresponds to a schema.

arguments.name: SCHEMA_SERVER=
arguments.description: Specifies the server name or IP address of the server that stores the schema mapping.

arguments.name: server-name
arguments.description: specifies the server that stores the schema definition for a collection.

arguments.name: SCHEMA_SSL_CA=
arguments.description: Specifies the full path name to the certificate authority file for the MongoDB schema location.

arguments.name: SCHEMA_SSL_CERT=
arguments.description: Specifies the full path name to the certificate file for the MongoDB schema location.

arguments.name: SCHEMA_TABLES=
arguments.description: Specifies whether to create tables that give details about a schema.

arguments.name: YESNO
arguments.description: specifies whether to create the schema detail tables.

arguments.name: SCHEMA_USER=
arguments.description: Specifies the user ID that corresponds to a schema.

arguments.name: user-ID
arguments.description: specifies the user ID that corresponds to a schema.

arguments.name: SCRATCH_DB=
arguments.description: Specifies a Hive schema so that SAS can store temporary output.

arguments.name: schema-name
arguments.description: specifies the name that is assigned to a logical classification of objects in a relational database.

arguments.name: SERVER=
arguments.description: specifies the server, host name, or IP address used when building the JDBC URL connection string. This option is ignored when the URL= option is specified.

arguments.name: SERVERPREFETCH=
arguments.description: Modifies the number of cached rowsets to be used in server-side prefetching.
arguments.help: SERVERPREFETCH= 0  | OFF | FALSE | NO | 1 | ON | TRUE | YES | *unsigned-integer*

arguments.name: SERVICE=
arguments.description: Specifies the service name or port number for the SPD Server’s name server.

arguments.name: SESSIONS=
arguments.description: Specifies how many Teradata sessions to be logged on when using FastLoad, FastExport, or Multiload.

arguments.name: number-of-sessions
arguments.description: specifies a numeric value that indicates the number of sessions to be logged on.

arguments.name: SESSREF=
arguments.description: Specifies the name of the CAS session to which you want to connect.

arguments.name: SFORCE
arguments.description: specifies the SAS/ACCESS engine name for the Salesforce interface.

arguments.name: SHARE=
arguments.description: Enables enhanced sharing of user proxies.

arguments.name: SHOWFLAGS=
arguments.description: Specifies whether the columns Questionable, Annotated, and Substituted display.

arguments.name: YES
arguments.description: displays the Questionable, Annotated, and Substituted columns.

arguments.name: NO
arguments.description: displays only the Tag, Timestamp, Value, and Status columns.

arguments.name: SHOW_METADATA=
arguments.description: Specifies whether to display metadata tables and columns.

arguments.name: YES
arguments.description: specifies that the SAS/ACCESS engine displays metadata tables and columns.

arguments.name: NO
arguments.description: specifies that SAS/ACCESS engine does not display metadata tables and columns.

arguments.name: SHOW_RECYCLED=
arguments.description: Specifies whether to display deleted table rows in the recycle bin.

arguments.name: YES
arguments.description: specifies that recently deleted table rows are displayed in the recycle bin.

arguments.name: NO
arguments.description: specifies that recently deleted table rows are not displayed in the recycle bin.

arguments.name: SHOW_SYNONYMS=
arguments.description: Specifies whether synonyms only or tables, views, or materialized views are available through your LIBNAME connection.

arguments.name: YES
arguments.description: specifies that only synonyms that represent tables, views, or materialized views are available through a LIBNAME connection.

arguments.name: NO
arguments.description: specifies that only tables, views, or materialized views are available through a LIBNAME connection.

arguments.name: SKIP_IDENTITY_COL=
arguments.description: Specifies whether to skip IDENTITY columns when writing to an external table.

arguments.name: YESNO
arguments.description: specifies whether to skip IDENTITY columns when writing to an external table.

arguments.name: SLEEP=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of minutes that FastExport, FastLoad, or MultiLoad waits before trying again to log on to Teradata.

arguments.name: number-of-minutes
arguments.description: the number of minutes to wait before trying again to log on to Teradata.

arguments.name: SNOW
arguments.description: specifies the SAS/ACCESS engine name for the Snowflake interface.

arguments.name: SPARK
arguments.description: specifies the SAS/ACCESS engine name for the Spark interface.

arguments.name: SPDE
arguments.description: The SPD Engine is designed for shigh-speed processing of very large tables and uses threads to read data rapidly and in parallel, executing on multiple CPUs.

arguments.name: SPOOL=
arguments.description: Specifies whether SAS creates a utility spool file during Read transactions that read data more than once.

arguments.name: YES
arguments.description: specifies that SAS creates a utility spool file into which it writes the rows that are read the first time. For subsequent passes through the data, the rows are read from the utility spool file rather than being reread from the DBMS table. This guarantees that the rowset is the same for every pass through the data.

arguments.name: NO
arguments.description: specifies that the required rows for all passes of the data are read from the DBMS table. No spool file is written. There is no guarantee that the rowset is the same for each pass through the data.

arguments.name: DBMS
arguments.description: specifies that the required rows for all passes of the data are read from the DBMS table. However, additional enforcements are made on the DBMS server side to ensure that the rowset is the same for every pass through the data. This value causes SAS/ACCESS Interface to Oracle to satisfy the two-pass requirement by starting a read-only transaction. SPOOL=YES and SPOOL=DBMS have comparable performance results for Oracle. However, SPOOL=DBMS does not use any disk space. When SPOOL is set to DBMS, you must specify CONNECTION=UNIQUE or an error occurs.

arguments.name: SQLGENERATION=
arguments.description: Specifies whether SAS procedures generate SQL for in-database processing of source data.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: prevents those SAS procedures that are enabled for in-database processing from generating SQL for in-database processing.

arguments.name: DBMS
arguments.description: allows those SAS procedures that are enabled for in-database processing to generate SQL for in-database processing.

arguments.name: SQLSVR
arguments.description: specifies the SAS/ACCESS engine name for the Microsoft SQL Server interface.

arguments.name: SQL_FUNCTIONS=
arguments.description: Customizes the in-memory SQL dictionary function list for this particular LIBNAME statement.

arguments.name: ALL
arguments.description: customizes the in-memory SQL dictionary function list for this particular LIBNAME statement by adding the set of all existing functions, even those that might be risky or untested.

arguments.name: EXTERNAL_REPLACE=
arguments.description: indicates a user-specified, external SAS data set from which the complete function list in the SQL dictionary is to be built. The assumption is that the user has already issued a LIBNAME statement to the directory where the SAS data set exists.

arguments.name: EXTERNAL_APPEND=
arguments.description: indicates a user-specified, external SAS data set from which additional functions are to be added to the existing function list in the SQL dictionary. The assumption is that the user has already issued a LIBNAME statement to the directory where the SAS data set exists.

arguments.name: SQL_FUNCTIONS_COPY=
arguments.description: Specifies whether to write the functions that are associated with a LIBNAME statement to a SAS data set or the SAS log.

arguments.name: libref.member
arguments.description: writes the current in-memory function list to a user-specified SAS data set for this particular LIBNAME statement.

arguments.name: SASLOG
arguments.description: writes the current in-memory function list to the SAS log for this particular LIBNAME statement.

arguments.name: SQL_OJ_ANSI=
arguments.description: Specifies whether to pass ANSI outer-join syntax through to the database.

arguments.name: YES
arguments.description: specifies that ANSI outer-join syntax is passed through to the database.

arguments.name: NO
arguments.description: disables pass-through of ANSI outer-joins.

arguments.name: key-string
arguments.description: specifies your Google Cloud Storage key as a string rather than as a file.

arguments.name: STORAGE_PLATFORM=
arguments.description: Specifies the type of cloud storage system.

arguments.name: ADLS
arguments.description: specifies Microsoft Azure Data Lake Storage Gen2.

arguments.name: AWS
arguments.description: specifies Amazon S3.

arguments.name: GCS
arguments.description: specifies Google Cloud Storage.

arguments.name: STORAGE_SHARED_KEY=
arguments.description: Specifies the account key for connecting to Microsoft Azure.

arguments.name: "string"
arguments.description: specifies the account key, which you can copy from the assignment in the Microsoft Azure portal. Note that the Parquet engine uses an account key for authentication instead of device code flow authentication.

arguments.name: STORAGE_TIMEOUT=
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum completion time for connecting to a cloud storage system.

arguments.name: n
arguments.description: specifies the maximum number of seconds for a storage task to complete. The time-out is not enforced by SAS. If the storage system is enabled to enforce a time-out, then the storage system returns an error if the task does not complete within the specified time.

arguments.name: STRINGDATES=
aliases:
STRDATES= [Greenplum, Microsoft SQL
      Server, PostgreSQL, Yellowbrick]
arguments.description: Specifies whether to read date and time values from the database as character strings.

arguments.name: YES
arguments.description: specifies that SAS reads date and time values as character strings.

arguments.name: NO
arguments.description: specifies that SAS reads date and time values as numeric date values.

arguments.name: SUB_CHAR=
arguments.description: Specifies a substitution character to use in place of any invalid characters that cannot be represented in the SAS session encoding.

arguments.name: value
arguments.description: specifies the substitution character to use in place of a character that cannot be represented in the SAS session encoding.

arguments.name: SYBBUFSZ=
arguments.description: specifies the number of rows of DBMS data to write to the buffer. If this statement is used, the SAS/ACCESS interface view engine creates a buffer that is large enough to hold the specified number of rows. This buffer is created when the associated database table is read. The interface view engine uses SYBBUFSZ= to improve performance. If you omit this statement, no data is written to the buffer.

arguments.name: SYNONYMS=
arguments.description: Specifies whether PROC DATASETS shows synonyms, tables, views, or materialized views for the current user and schema if you specified the SCHEMA= option.

arguments.name: YES
arguments.description: specifies that PROC DATASETS shows only synonyms that represent tables, views, or materialized views for the current user.

arguments.name: NO
arguments.description: specifies that PROC DATASETS shows only tables, views, or materialized views for the current user.

arguments.name: SYSNR=
arguments.description: Indicates the SAP system number—the 2-byte code that identifies the system on the host.

arguments.name: TABLE_TYPE=
arguments.description: Specifies the type of temporary tables and table storage when the engine creates tables in SAP HANA.
arguments.help:
TABLE_TYPE= ROW |  COLUMN\nTABLE_TYPE= LOCAL |  GLOBAL\nTABLE_TYPE= (COLUMN
                LOCAL)

arguments.name: ROW
arguments.description: creates a table using ROW-based storage in SAP HANA.

arguments.name: COLUMN
arguments.description: creates a table using COLUMN-based storage in SAP HANA.

arguments.name: TAG=
arguments.description: Specifies a multi-level prefix for a CAS table that is used to identify the table to both the CAS server and SAS.

arguments.name: TAGSET=
arguments.description: Specifies the name of a tagset to override the default tagset that is used by the specified markup type.

arguments.name: tagset-name
arguments.description: is the name of a tagset to override the default tagset that is used by the markup type that is specified with XMLTYPE=.

arguments.name: TDPID=
arguments.description: specifies a required connection option if you run more than one Teradata server.

arguments.name: dbcname
arguments.description: specifies an entry in your (client) HOSTS file that provides an IP address for a database server connection.

arguments.name: TEMP=
arguments.description: Creates a temporary server domain for this LIBNAME assignment.

arguments.name: TEMPORAL_QUALIFIER=
arguments.description: Specifies time-dimension criteria for retrieving data from Teradata.
arguments.help:
TEMPORAL_QUALIFIER= CURRENT VALIDTIME | 
	 VALIDTIME AS OF PERIOD 'period' | 
	SEQUENCED VALIDTIME PERIOD 'period' | 
	 NONSEQUENCED VALIDTIME PERIOD 'period'\nTEMPORAL_QUALIFIER= CURRENT TRANSACTIONTIME | 
	TRANSACTIONTIME AS OF 'period' |  
	NONSEQUENCED TRANSACTIONTIME

arguments.name: CURRENT
arguments.description: selects rows that are valid at the current time.

arguments.name: VALIDTIME
arguments.description: selects rows with valid-time periods that overlap the specified AS OF period. For the period, you can specify either a single date or a time period (date range) by specifying a start date and an end date.

arguments.name: SEQUENCED
arguments.description: selects history, current, or future rows that are valid for the specified time period.

arguments.name: NONSEQUENCED
arguments.description: treats the table as nontemporal.

arguments.name: TEMP_CTAS=
arguments.description: Specifies whether to create an intermediate (temporary) table in Hive.

arguments.name: TENACITY=
arguments.description: Specifies how many hours that FastExport, FastLoad, or MultiLoad continues to try to log on again to Teradata if the maximum number of Teradata utilities are already running.

arguments.name: number-of-hours
arguments.description: specifies the number of hours to continue to try again to log on to Teradata.

arguments.name: TERADATA
arguments.description: specifies the SAS/ACCESS engine name for the Teradata interface.

arguments.name: TEZ_QUEYE_NAME=
arguments.description: specifies an Apache Tez queue name in which to execute client requests.

arguments.name: TIMEOUTSECONDS=
arguments.description: Specifies the client inactivity time-out interval in seconds. If SAS stops transferring data to the server, the server starts the inactivity timer for the specified duration and cancels the request if SAS does not resume data transfer.

arguments.name: TIMEZONE=
arguments.description: Specifies whether SAS writes timestamps to result data using local time or GMT.

arguments.name: LOCAL
arguments.description: specifies to use the local time to write timestamps to result data in SAS.

arguments.name: GMT
arguments.description: specifies to use GMT to write timestamps to result data in SAS.

arguments.name: TPT=
arguments.description: Specifies whether SAS uses the Teradata Parallel Transporter (TPT) API to load data when SAS requests a Fastload, MultiLoad, or Multi-Statement insert.

arguments.name: YES
arguments.description: specifies that SAS uses the TPT API when Fastload, MultiLoad, or Multi-Statement insert is requested.

arguments.name: NO
arguments.description: specifies that SAS does not use the TPT API when Fastload, MultiLoad, or Multi-Statement insert is requested.

arguments.name: TPT_DATA_ENCRYPTION=
arguments.description: Specifies whether to encrypt SQL requests, responses, and data when using the Teradata Parallel Transport (TPT) API.

arguments.name: YESNO
arguments.description: specifies whether to encrypt SQL requests, responses, and data when using the TPT API.

arguments.name: TPT_MAX_SESSIONS=
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum number of sessions for Teradata to use when using the TPT API with FastLoad, MultiLoad, or Multi-Statement insert.

arguments.name: integer
arguments.description: specifies the maximum number of sessions for Teradata to use when using the TPT API to load data with FastLoad, MultiLoad, or Multi-Statement insert.

arguments.name: TPT_MIN_SESSIONS=
arguments.description: Specifies the minimum number of sessions for Teradata to use when using the TPT API with FastLoad, MultiLoad, or Multi-Statement insert.

arguments.name: integer
arguments.description: specifies the minimum number of sessions for Teradata to use when using the TPT API to load data with FastLoad, MultiLoad, or Multi-Statement insert.

arguments.name: TPT_UNICODE_PASSTHRU=
arguments.description: Specifies whether to allow pass-through characters (PTC) to be loaded into SAS or written to Teradata.

arguments.name: TRACE=
arguments.description: Specifies whether to turn on tracing information for use in debugging.

arguments.name: YES
arguments.description: specifies that tracing is turned on, and the DBMS driver manager writes each function call to the trace file that TRACEFILE= specifies.

arguments.name: NO
arguments.description: specifies that tracing is not turned on.

arguments.name: TRACEFILE=
arguments.description: Specifies the file name to which the DBMS driver manager writes trace information.

arguments.name: TRACEFLAGS=
arguments.description: Specifies whether to record column, time, and other parameter data in the trace file.
arguments.help: TRACEFLAGS= ALL | COLBINDINGS | GETDATA | PUTDATA | TIMESTAMP

arguments.name: ALL
arguments.description: enables tracing of all information that is available via this option.

arguments.name: COLBINDINGS
arguments.description: enables tracing of column information for Read and Write operations.

arguments.name: GETDATA
arguments.description: enables tracing of Read operations.

arguments.name: PUTDATA
arguments.description: enables tracing of Write operations.

arguments.name: TIMESTAMP
arguments.description: enables tracing of time-related data.

arguments.name: TRANSCODE_FAIL=
arguments.description: Lets you specify how to handle processing and notification of transcoding errors.

arguments.name: ERROR
arguments.description: stops processing data and provides an informative error message.

arguments.name: WARNING
arguments.description: continues processing of data but provides an informative error message.

arguments.name: SILENT
arguments.description: continues processing of data but suppresses messages.

arguments.name: TRANSERRORCOMPATMODE=
arguments.description: Indicates whether transcoding errors are reported.

arguments.name: TRUNCWARN=
arguments.description: Suppresses hard failure on NLS transcoding overflow and character mapping errors.

arguments.name: TRUST_STORE_PASSWORD=
arguments.description: specifies the password for the truststore .

arguments.name: TR_ENABLE_INTERRUPT=
arguments.description: Allows interruption of any long-running SQL processes that are involved in creating the result set or spool file.

arguments.name: YES
arguments.description: allows interruption of long-running SQL processes that are involved in creating the result set or spool file.

arguments.name: NO
arguments.description: disables the interrupt processing code path.

arguments.name: UNIXDOMAIN=
arguments.description: Specifies to use UNIX domain sockets for data transfers between the client and SPD Server.

arguments.name: UPDATEBUFF=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of rows that are processed in a single DBMS Update or Delete operation.

arguments.name: positive-integer
arguments.description: the number of rows in an operation. SAS allows the maximum that the DBMS allows.

arguments.name: UPDATE_ISOLATION_LEVEL=
arguments.description: Specifies the degree of isolation of the current application process from other concurrently running application processes.

arguments.name: UPDATE_LOCK_TYPE=
arguments.description: Specifies how data in a DBMS table is locked during an update transaction.
arguments.help: UPDATE_LOCK_TYPE= ROW |   PAGE |   TABLE |   NOLOCK |  VIEW

arguments.name: ROW
arguments.description: locks a row if any of its columns are to be updated.

arguments.name: PAGE
arguments.description: locks a page of data. The number of bytes in a page is specific to the DBMS.

arguments.name: TABLE
arguments.description: locks the entire DBMS table.

arguments.name: NOLOCK
arguments.description: does not lock the DBMS table, page, or any rows when reading them for update.

arguments.name: VIEW
arguments.description: locks the entire DBMS view.

arguments.name: UPDATE_MODE_WAIT=
arguments.description: Specifies during SAS/ACCESS Update operations whether Teradata should wait to acquire a lock or fail the request when a different user has locked the DBMS resource.

arguments.name: YES
arguments.description: specifies for Teradata to wait to acquire the lock, so SAS/ACCESS waits indefinitely until it can acquire the lock.

arguments.name: NO
arguments.description: specifies that Teradata fails the lock request if the specified DBMS resource is locked.

arguments.name: UPDATE_MULT_ROWS=
arguments.description: Indicates whether SAS updates multiple rows from a data source, such as a DBMS table.

arguments.name: YES
arguments.description: specifies that SAS/ACCESS processing continues if multiple rows are updated. This might produce unexpected results.

arguments.name: NO
arguments.description: specifies that SAS/ACCESS processing does not continue if multiple rows are updated.

arguments.name: UPDATE_SQL=
arguments.description: Specifies whether SAS uses current-of-cursor SQL to update and delete rows in a data source.

arguments.name: YES
arguments.description: specifies that SAS/ACCESS uses Current-of-Cursor SQL to update or delete rows in a table.

arguments.name: NO
arguments.description: specifies that SAS/ACCESS uses the SQLSetPos() application programming interface (API) to update or delete rows in a table.

arguments.name: URI=
arguments.description: specifies the user name to connect to Hive and read and write to HDFS, if available. Do not use the USER= argument if your Hadoop cluster is secured by Kerberos.

arguments.name: URL=
arguments.description: specifies the JDBC URL to connect to Databricks or Spark SQL.

arguments.name: USER=
arguments.description: specifies the user name for connecting to the data source.

arguments.name: USE_DATADIRECT=
arguments.description: Specifies the driver to use.

arguments.name: YES
arguments.description: specifies to use the DataDirect driver.

arguments.name: NO
arguments.description: specifies to use the Cloudera driver.

arguments.name: USE_INFORMATION_SCHEMA=
arguments.description: Specifies whether to use INFORMATION_SCHEMA in Google BigQuery to retrieve a list of schemas and tables or views.

arguments.name: USE_NATIVE_NAMES=
arguments.description: Specifies whether to restore native naming conventions for custom tables and columns.

arguments.name: YES
arguments.description: restores the native naming convention of using the __c suffix with custom tables and columns.

arguments.name: NO
arguments.description: retains the current names for custom tables and columns. By default,the __c suffix at the end of custom table and column names is not displayed, and no suffix is needed to update component fields.

arguments.name: USE_ODBC_CL=
arguments.description: Indicates whether the Driver Manager uses the ODBC Cursor Library.

arguments.name: YES
arguments.description: specifies that the Driver Manager uses the ODBC Cursor Library. The ODBC Cursor Library supports block scrollable cursors and positioned update and delete statements.

arguments.name: NO
arguments.description: specifies that the Driver Manager uses the scrolling capabilities of the driver.

arguments.name: USE_PIPELINE=
arguments.description: Enables pipeline read functionality for Amazon Redshift.

arguments.name: NO
arguments.description: fetches rows directly to the main SAS read buffer. The main SAS read buffer runs in a single thread.

arguments.name: YES
arguments.description: specifies to leverage multi-thread technology to improve read performance.

arguments.name: USE_SSL=
arguments.description: Specifies whether to use TLS encryption for connections.

arguments.name: USING=
arguments.description: specifies the password that is associated with the user.

arguments.name: password
arguments.description: specifies the password that is associated with the user.

arguments.name: UTILCONN_TRANSIENT=
arguments.description: Specifies whether a utility connection is automatically dropped as soon as it is no longer in use.

arguments.name: NO
arguments.description: specifies that a utility connection is maintained for the lifetime of the libref.

arguments.name: YES
arguments.description: specifies that a utility connection is automatically dropped as soon as it is no longer in use.

arguments.name: UUID=
arguments.description: Connects the CAS engine to the CAS session that is identified in the UUID.

arguments.name: UUIDMAC=
arguments.description: Specifies a macro variable that stores a UUID for any session created by the engine.

arguments.name: V9
arguments.description: specifies the default engine for accessing SAS files in Base SAS.

arguments.name: VERTICA
arguments.description: specifies the SAS/ACCESS engine name for the Vertica interface.

arguments.name: WAREHOUSE=
arguments.description: specifies the default Snowflake warehouse to use for sessions that the driver initiated.

arguments.name: WARN_BIGINT
arguments.description: specifies whether to issue a warning in the SAS log if the INT8 data type is in a DBMS table.

arguments.name: YESNO
arguments.description: specifies whether to issue a warning in the SAS log if DBMS data contains INT8 data.

arguments.name: WARN_BIGINT=
arguments.description: issues a warning in the SAS log if the BIGINT data type is in a DBMS table.

arguments.name: YES
arguments.description: issues a warning in the SAS log if a BIGINT data type is in a DBMS table.

arguments.name: NO
arguments.description: specifies that the warning for a BIGINT data type does not appear in the SAS log.

arguments.name: WRITETRANSFERSIZE=
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum number of bytes that the CAS engine writes when transferring data to the CAS server.

arguments.name: XLSX
arguments.description: is the SAS LIBNAME engine name for reading and writing Microsoft Excel files in the .xlsx file format.

arguments.name: XMLCONCATENATE=
arguments.description: Specifies whether the file to be imported contains multiple, concatenated XML documents.

arguments.name: NO
arguments.description: specifies that the file to be imported does not contain concatenated XML documents.

arguments.name: YES
arguments.description: specifies that the file to be imported contains multiple, concatenated XML documents.

arguments.name: XMLDATAFORM=
arguments.description: Specifies whether the tag for the element to contain SAS variable information (name and data) is in open-element or enclosed-attribute format.

arguments.name: ELEMENT
arguments.description: specifies that the tag is in open-element format.

arguments.name: ATTRIBUTE
arguments.description: specifies that the tag is in enclosed-attribute format.

arguments.name: XMLDOUBLE=
arguments.description: Controls the results of importing or exporting numeric values.

arguments.name: DISPLAY
arguments.description:
when exporting, the engine retrieves the stored value for the numeric variable, determines an appropriate display for the value in a readable form, and writes the display value to the XML document. The display value is affected by the engine and whether a format is assigned.
• The XML engine uses an assigned format. The maximum value is 16 digits. For example, if a numeric variable has an assigned format width that is 20 digits, such as BEST20., the engine truncates the exported value. If there is not an assigned format, the engine displays the value using BEST10.
• The XMLV2 engine ignores any assigned format and displays the value using BEST16.

arguments.name: INTERNAL
arguments.description: when exporting, the engine retrieves the stored value for the numeric variable and writes the raw value to a generated attribute value pair (of the form rawvalue="value"). SAS uses the base64 encoding of a portable machine representation. (The base64 encoding method converts binary data into ASCII text and vice versa and is similar to the MIME format.)

arguments.name: XMLENCODING=
arguments.description: Overrides the SAS data set's encoding for the output file.

arguments.name: 'encoding-value'
arguments.description: specifies an encoding value. If the value contains a hyphen, enclose the value in quotation marks.

arguments.name: XMLFILEREF=
arguments.description: Specifies an XML document to be exported or imported.

arguments.name: fileref
arguments.description: is the SAS name that is assigned to the physical location of the XML document to be exported or imported.

arguments.name: XMLMAP=
arguments.description: Specifies an XML document that contains specific XMLMap syntax.

arguments.name: fileref
arguments.description: is the SAS name that is assigned to the physical location of the XMLMap. To assign a fileref, use the FILENAME statement.

arguments.name: 'XMLMap-location'
arguments.description: is the physical location of the XMLMap.

arguments.name: XMLMETA=
arguments.description: Specifies whether to include metadata-related information in the exported markup, or specifies whether to import metadata-related information that is included in the input XML document.

arguments.name: DATA
arguments.description: ignores metadata-related information. DATA includes only data content in the exported markup and imports only data content in the input XML document.

arguments.name: SCHEMADATA
arguments.description: includes both data content and metadata-related information in the exported markup and imports both data content and metadata-related information in the input XML document.

arguments.name: SCHEMA
arguments.description: ignores data content. SCHEMA includes only metadata-related information in the exported markup and imports only metadata-related information in the input XML document.

arguments.name: XMLPROCESS=
arguments.description: Determines how the engine processes character data that does not conform to W3C specifications.

arguments.name: CONFORM
arguments.description: requires that the XML conform to W3C specifications. W3C specifications state that for character data, certain characters such as the left angle bracket (<), the ampersand (&), and the apostrophe (') must be escaped using character references or strings like &. For example, to allow attribute values to contain both single and double quotation marks, the apostrophe or single quotation mark character (') can be represented as ' and the double quotation mark character (") can be represented as ".

arguments.name: PERMIT
arguments.description: permits character data that does not conform to W3C specifications to be accepted. That is, in character data, non-escaped characters such as the apostrophe, double quotation marks, and the ampersand are accepted.

arguments.name: XMLSCHEMA=
arguments.description: Specifies an external file to contain metadata-related information.

arguments.name: fileref
arguments.description: is the SAS name that is assigned to the physical location of the output file. To assign a fileref, use the FILENAME statement.

arguments.name: 'external-file'
arguments.description: is the physical location of the file to contain the metadata-related information. Include the complete path name and the file name. Enclose the physical name in single or double quotation marks.

arguments.name: XMLTYPE=
arguments.description: Specifies the XML markup type.
arguments.help: XMLTYPE= GENERIC | CDISCODM | MSACCESS | ORACLE | XMLMAP

arguments.name: GENERIC
arguments.description: is a simple, well-formed XML markup type. The XML document consists of a root (enclosing) element and repeating element instances. GENERIC determines a variable's attributes from the data content.

arguments.name: CDISCODM
arguments.description: is the XML markup type for the markup standards that are defined in the Operational Data Model (ODM) that was created by the Clinical Data Interchange Standards Consortium (CDISC). The XML engine supports the ODM 1.2 schema specification. ODM supports the electronic acquisition, exchange, and archiving of clinical trials data and metadata for medical and biopharmaceutical product development.

arguments.name: MSACCESS
arguments.description: is the XML markup type for the markup standards supported for a Microsoft Access database (.mdb). If the Microsoft Access file contains metadata-related information, then you must specify MSACCESS rather than the default GENERIC markup type. If there is an embedded XML schema, specifying MSACCESS and the XMLMETA=SCHEMADATA option causes a variable's attributes to be obtained from the embedded schema. If there is not an embedded schema, MSACCESS uses default values for attributes.

arguments.name: ORACLE
arguments.description: is the XML markup type for the markup standards equivalent to the Oracle 8i XML implementation. The number of columns to indent each nested element is one, and the enclosing element tag for the contents of the SAS data set is ROWSET.

arguments.name: XMLMAP
arguments.description: specifies that XML markup is determined by an XMLMap, which is an XML document that you create that contains specific XMLMap syntax.

arguments.name: XMLV2
arguments.description: specifies the XMLV2 engine, which accesses the current engine functionality.

arguments.name: YBRICK
arguments.description: specifies the SAS/ACCESS engine name for the Yellowbrick interface.

arguments.name: ZOOKEEPER_NAMESPACE=
arguments.description: specifies the ZooKeeper namespace.

arguments.name: ZOOKEEPER_PORT=
arguments.description: specifies the port number that ZooKeeper listens to for client requests.

arguments.name: ZOOKEEPER_QUORUM=
arguments.description: specifies the server nodes that are available to run client requests. Separate node names using commas.

name: LOCK
description: Acquires, lists, or releases an exclusive lock on an existing SAS file.
help:
LOCK  libref<.member-name<.member-type | .entry-name.entry-type>> 
	<LIST | QUERY | SHOW | CLEAR | NOMSG>;

arguments.name: libref
arguments.description: is a name that is associated with a SAS library. The libref (library reference) must be a valid SAS name. If the libref is Sasuser or Work, you must specify it.

arguments.name: member-name
arguments.description: is a valid SAS name that specifies a member of the SAS library that is associated with the libref.

arguments.name: member-type
arguments.description: is the type of SAS file to be locked. For example, valid values are DATA, VIEW, CATALOG, MDDB, and so on. The default is DATA.

arguments.name: entry-name
arguments.description: is the name of the catalog entry to be locked.

arguments.name: entry-type
arguments.description: is the type of catalog entry to be locked.

arguments.name: LIST
arguments.description: writes to the SAS log whether you have an exclusive lock on the specified SAS file.

arguments.name: QUERY
arguments.description: writes to the SAS log whether you have an exclusive lock on the specified SAS file.

arguments.name: SHOW
arguments.description: writes to the SAS log whether you have an exclusive lock on the specified SAS file.

arguments.name: CLEAR
arguments.description: releases a lock on the specified SAS file that was acquired using the LOCK statement in your SAS session.

arguments.name: NOMSG
arguments.description: specifies that warnings and error messages are not written to the SAS log. NOMSG does not suppress notes that tell you that a lock is successful or that a lock is cleared.

name: MISSING
description: Assigns characters in your input data to represent special missing values for numeric data.

arguments.name: character
arguments.description: is the value in your input data that represents a special missing value.

name: ODS CSV
description: Opens, manages, or closes the CSV destination, which produces CSV output containing columns of data values that are separated by commas and produces tabular output.
help:
ODS CSV  <(<ID => identifier)> <action> ;
ODS CSV  <(<ID => identifier)> <options> ;

arguments.name: BODY=
arguments.description: Open a markup family destination and specify the file that contains the primary output that is created by the ODS statement

arguments.name: external-file
arguments.description: is the name of an external output file.

arguments.name: fileref
arguments.description: is a file reference that has been assigned to an external file. Use the FILENAME statement to assign a fileref.

arguments.name: entry.markup
arguments.description: specifies an entry in a SAS catalog to write to.

arguments.name: DOM
arguments.description: Specify that the ODS document object model is written to the SAS Log or to an external file

arguments.name: external-file
arguments.description: is the name of an external output file.

arguments.name: ENCODING=
arguments.description: Override the encoding for input or output processing (transcodes) of external files

arguments.name: EVENT=
arguments.description: Specify an event and the value for event variables that is associated with the event
arguments.help: EVENT= (FILE=*event-name* | FINISH | LABEL= | NAME= | START | STYLE= | TARGET= | TEXT= | URL= )

arguments.name: (FILE=)
arguments.description: triggers one of the known types of output files that correspond to the BODY=, CODE=, CONTENTS=, FRAME=, PAGES=, and STYLESHEET= options.
arguments.help: (FILE= BODY | CODE | CONTENTS | DATA | FRAME | PAGES | STYLESHEET)

arguments.name: (FINISH)
arguments.description: triggers the finish section of an event.

arguments.name: (LABEL='')
arguments.description: specifies the value for the LABEL event variable.

arguments.name: (NAME='')
arguments.description: specifies the value for the NAME event variable.

arguments.name: (START)
arguments.description: triggers the start section of an event.

arguments.name: (STYLE=)
arguments.description: specifies a style element.

arguments.name: (TARGET='')
arguments.description: specifies the value for the TARGET event variable.

arguments.name: (TEXT='')
arguments.description: specifies the value for the TEXT event variable.

arguments.name: (URL='')
arguments.description: specifies the value for the URL event variable.

arguments.name: (ID= )
arguments.description: Open multiple instances of the same destination at the same time

arguments.name: identifier
arguments.description: specifies another instance of the destination that is already open. identifier is numeric or a series of characters that begin with a letter or an underscore. Subsequent characters can include letters, underscores, and numeric characters.

arguments.name: NEWFILE=
arguments.description: Create a new body file at the specified starting point

arguments.name: BYGROUP
arguments.description: starts a new file for the results of each BY group.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: writes all output to the body file that is currently open.

arguments.name: OUTPUT
arguments.description: starts a new body file for each output object. For SAS/GRAPH this means that ODS creates a new file for each SAS/GRAPH output file that the program generates.

arguments.name: PAGE
arguments.description: starts a new body file for each page of output. A page break occurs when a procedure explicitly starts a new page (not because the page size was exceeded) or when you start a new procedure.

arguments.name: PROC
arguments.description: starts a new body file each time you start a new procedure.

arguments.name: OPTIONS
arguments.description: Specify tagset-specific suboptions and a named value

arguments.name: (DOC=''''''
arguments.description: provides information about the specified tagset.

arguments.name: HELP
arguments.description: provides generic help and information with a quick reference.

arguments.name: QUICK
arguments.description: describes the options available for this tagset.

arguments.name: SETTINGS
arguments.description: provides the current option settings.

arguments.name: CHANGELOG
arguments.description: lists a history of changes made to the tagset. This suboption is supported only on the RTF tagset.

arguments.name: suboptions
arguments.description: specifies one or more suboptions that are valid for the specified tagset. Suboptions have the following format.

arguments.name: PACKAGE
arguments.description: Specify that the output from the destination be added to an ODS package

arguments.name: package-name
arguments.description: specifies the name of a package that was created with the ODS PACKAGE statement. If no name is specified, then the output is added to the unnamed package that was opened last.

arguments.name: PATH=
arguments.description: Specify the location of an aggregate storage location or a SAS catalog for all markup files

arguments.name: 'aggregate-file-storage-location'
arguments.description: specifies an aggregate storage location such as directory, folder, or partitioned data set.

arguments.name: fileref
arguments.description: is a file reference that has been assigned to an aggregate storage location. Use the FILENAME statement to assign a fileref.

arguments.name: libref.catalog

arguments.name: BRANCH=
arguments.description: specifies that an entry for the chapter is to be created in the table of contents for the EPUB book. ODS EPUB does not automatically create table of contents entries for nonlinear output. BRANCH events can be nested to build nested table of contents entries. Match up the START and FINISH options to the desired depth.

arguments.name: FIGURE=
arguments.description: adds figures that are embedded in the e-book book. This block contains a single image. ODS EPUB implements FIGURE as an event.

arguments.name: START
arguments.description: starts the code block that embeds the figure.

arguments.name: FINISH
arguments.description: ends the code block that embeds the figure.

arguments.name: FIGCAPTION=
arguments.description: adds text to the figure. This option provides markup for captioned content that is self-contained and can be separated from the main flow of the document. A figure can contain one caption and it must appear first or last in the caption content. ODS EPUB implements FIGCAPTION as an event. The FIGCAPTION event accepts TEXT, which is the text to be displayed above or below the content.

arguments.description: starts a new chapter for each page of output. A page break occurs when you start a new procedure, or when a procedure explicitly starts a new page.

arguments.description: Specify destination-specific suboptions and a space-delimited named value for how e-books are handled

arguments.name: (CHAPTER_TYPE=’’)
arguments.description: Specifies the type of the current chapter. The type is one or more space-delimited terms defined by EPUB 3 Structural Semantics Vocabulary. For more information, see https://idpf.github.io/epub-vocabs/structure/.

arguments.name: (CONTENTS=')
arguments.description: generates a table of contents.

arguments.name: OFF
arguments.description: does not generate a table of contents.

arguments.name: ON
arguments.description: generates a table of contents.

arguments.name: (CONTRIBUTOR='')
arguments.description: specifies one or more contributor’s names responsible for making contributions to the content of the e-book. Delimit multiple contributors with commas.

arguments.name: (COVER_IMAGE='')
arguments.description: specifies a cover image for the e-book.

arguments.name: (COVERAGE='')
arguments.description: specifies the extent or scope of the content of the e-book.

arguments.name: (CREATOR='')
arguments.description: specifies one or more primary creators or authors of the e-book.

arguments.name: (DEFEAT_Books_CACHING=)
arguments.description: defeats Books e-book reader's caching of e-books that have the same title.

arguments.name: OFF
arguments.description: caches Books of the same title.

arguments.name: ON
arguments.description: defeats Books caching.

arguments.name: (DESCRIPTION='')
arguments.description: specifies a description of the content of the e-book.

arguments.name: (EMBEDDED_FONTS='')
arguments.description: specifies a list of fonts to be embedded in the e-book.

arguments.name: (HIDE_CONTENTS=)
arguments.description: hides entries in a linear table of contents.

arguments.name: OFF
arguments.description: does not hide the entries in a linear table of contents.

arguments.name: ON
arguments.description: hides the entries in a linear table of contents.

arguments.name: (HIDE_LANDMARKS=)
arguments.description: hides entries in a linear table of landmarks.

arguments.name: OFF
arguments.description: does not hide the entries in a linear table of landmarks.

arguments.name: ON
arguments.description: hides the entries in a linear table of landmarks.

arguments.name: (ISBN='')
arguments.description: specifies a 13-digit International Standard Book Number (ISBN) for the e-book. For more information, see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number. If not specified, a Universally Unique Identifier (UUID) is generated for the e-book. For more information, see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Universally_unique_identifier.

arguments.name: (LANDMARK=
arguments.description: specifies the landmark for the current chapter. If 'AUTO' is specified, the landmark will be derived from the chapter type.

arguments.name: (LINEAR_NAV=)
arguments.description: specifies navigational aids to embed in the e-book.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: no navigational aids are embedded in the e-book.

arguments.name: CONTENTS
arguments.description: causes the table of contents to be embedded.

arguments.name: LANDMARKS
arguments.description: causes table of landmarks to be embedded.

arguments.name: ALL
arguments.description: causes the table of contents and the table of landmarks to be embedded.

arguments.name: (NONLINEAR=)
arguments.description: specifies output to be written to the non-linear section of the e-book.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: occurs within the linear flow of the e-book.

arguments.name: CHAPTER
arguments.description: causes the entire chapter to be non-linear.

arguments.name: BATCH
arguments.description: causes batch (preformatted) output to be non-linear.

arguments.name: TABLE
arguments.description: causes tables to be non-linear.

arguments.name: ALL
arguments.description: causes the entire chapter to be non-linear. This has the same effect as the CHAPTER value.

arguments.name: (OPTIMIZE_FOR_IBOOKS=)
arguments.description: optimizes for Books e-book reader.

arguments.name: OFF
arguments.description: overrides user-specified fonts.

arguments.name: ON
arguments.description: honors user-specified fonts.

arguments.name: (PAGEBREAK=)
arguments.description: honors explicit page breaks.

arguments.name: OFF
arguments.description: does not honor explicit page breaks.

arguments.name: ON
arguments.description: honors explicit page breaks.

arguments.name: AUTO
arguments.description: allows ODS and procedures to determine when page breaks occur. Honors explicit page breaks.

arguments.description: specifies the publisher of the e-book.

arguments.description: specifies a reference to a related resource.

arguments.name: (RIGHTS='')
arguments.description: specifies information about rights held in and over the e-book.

arguments.name: (SOURCE='')
arguments.description: specifies information about a prior resource from which the e-book was derived.

arguments.name: (START='')
arguments.description: specifies the component (chapter) at which an e-book first opens.

arguments.name: (SUBJECT='')

arguments.name: (ABSOLUTE_COLUMN_WIDTH ='')
arguments.description: specifies the column widths. Lists widths to use for columns instead of allowing SAS to determine the column width (measured widths). The number-list is a comma separated list of numbers. A value of 0 resets the default.

arguments.description: specifies the table body row heights. Specifying one number applies the same height value to all table body rows. arguments.description: specifies the range of columns to which filtering is applied. Acceptable values for the range are a numeric range (‘3-5’) or a column range (‘A:C’).
